There are fantastic old mansions with many historic markers and many consulates. Lots of good restaurants and not so much of the gaudy neon. Especially in late spring, summer and fall when the trees are full of leaves this is a great stroll and there are many parks to boot.

title: just love this part of the city...food, shopping, people watching
content: in a city with 20mil inhabitants, sky creepers everywhere and the globalised look we get in about every city in the world filled with The Guccis, Prada's, H&M, Zaras...this little part of town has its own chinese designers and some quality food and accessories, besides having parks and gree to walk though.

title: Interesting to see a good mix of old and new ...
content: Nice to walk and explore the quaint setup of the yester-years.  Guess it might be tougher to stroll about in summer because of heat.

title: lovely area to wander around
content: lovely little bars and restaurants away from the main thoroughfare very good quality food and lovely architecture.

user_loc: 弗吉尼亚亚历山德里亚
title: Great place to people watch and grab a bite to eat
content: I love visiting this part of Shanghai. Narrow streets with a variety of restaurants offering dishes from around the world.

title: Nice neighbourhood
content: French Concession is a great neighbourhood to walk around. There are a lot of small shops with all there own collections, so no big stores with big brands. Also there are a lot of small restaurants, even sometimes you think its nothing then you will be supriced as then there is a nice garden terras. This area is very much liked by the expats of Shanghai and if you go there you will know why.

title: Great architecture and some decent souvenir shopping
content: Guided tour of the area then left for an hours shopping before mini bus collected us some interesting nick naks

title: Interesting but forced.
content: There are some small element to the area such as the few original elements, and some locations of historical significance, but mostly just overpriced, westernised (not in a good way [and yes I realise this is the "French" concession]) shops and restaurants.

title: MMMMM universal studios??
content: I have wanted to go there for years and finally today I did....I had not realized that is was reconstructed! So felt very much like universal studios - it was cute and some nice little cafes but that is all - this is NOT history but made up from what it used to look like sadly. If you are in Shanghai you need to do something and this is one thing you could do.

title: Enterning into the past - a little
content: I had the pleasure of a local Shanghai person to explain to me the specialty about this area. The buildings are not old but built in an old fashioned way to commemorate how people lived in Shanghai in the past. Now it´s a place to see and be seen. Some nice restaurants and bars and I bet it´s quite a show at night time.

title: Not impressed....
content: Well,i come from Europe and for my is not much around. I was not attracted by the area. The architecture of the buildings is not ''wow'' to me. Lots of shops, restaurants and many other like anywhere else. I would NOT rank this place as a must.

title: Love, love, love.
content: This is a taste of rich culture... not to mention a wide variety of street food sold through countless vendors that line the streets. Go in the evening - while not a "night market", per se; the streets are teeming with activity after dark.

title: Investment pays off.
content: Someone had a vision to realize this project. It is growded the whole day long. Take time to see what the history is of the area. Any restaurant/bar is nice to go to. On off the few places in Shanghai with terraces.

user_loc: 南卡罗来纳希尔顿头岛
title: expansive and interesting...well worth a tour...self guided or guided
content: if time permits...do NOT miss.....and suggest that you end your tour at Sasha's. This is an old home coverted into quite a warm and friendly restaurant/bar.

title: So much to see & do!
content: One of the many things to see & do in Shanghai. Enjoyed Valentine's Day lunch and cocktails on a side street.

title: Cultural Backstreets
content: The old French concession is a lovely part of Shanghai that is a mixture of businesses, homes and restaurants/hotels. It has a lot of character compared with the glitzy areas of WaiTan on Lujiazui but it is best explored by foot. If you listen to locals going about their business and pop in and out of the small stores you will get a very real slice of Shanghai life, as it is presented to the foreign visitor. Truthfully, you will have to go more off the beaten track from the main streets to see the day-to-day living as it happens.

title: Best to visit by bike
content: You may start from DongHua DaXue university or just behind from the DingXi Lu/XinHua Lu intersection.

title: Know what you want to see
content: I wandered through the concession for three or four hours the first time through and saw nothing of interest. After doing some research and coming back, I was able to find points of interest. Know what you want to see as it is not really worth casual strolling, in my opinion.

title: It is being restored...
content: This area is being restored to its former glory...lots of up-scale restaurants, small hotels, boutiques and some private homes...it is beautiful to just wander around. The biggest surprise for me was when I came across a site being restored, with a large government sign that said "The French Concession - restoring our history".

title: Must see
content: The old French Concession area is a must see because it is so different from the rest of modern high rise Shanghai. There are lots of very nice shops, restaurants and bars in this area.

title: Old French Concession
content: Plenty of shopping around the little lanes and alleys. Old style architecture as well. Greta for photographers. Prices not bad , but be prepared to barter. Never pay advertised prices. Always look around before you commit. It may be cheaper 2 shops down.

title: Charming
content: Really beautiful colonial neighborhood.  Wonderful for a shady walk with a stop at a little cafe, bakery, or brew pub.  Fixing Street is terrific.

title: A most, definetely!
content: One of the most beautiful places in Shanghai. Shopping is great and you can find the best brands but also local designers. Food is really good and you can find different types and for every budget. This is definetely a most when going to Shaghai!

title: Lived here for 18 months! Loved it!
content:
The French Concession was my favourite place in Shanghai. Lots of little cafes and small streets lined with trees. Evenings are quiet and perfect for strolling. 
The architecture in the area is stunning. Take a map and just walk for a day!

title: Old world charm in a very modern city
content: The highlight of Shanghai. Great architecture - I am so glad this neighborhood has been preserved. I visited an old house that has been restored (sorry, I don't know the name/address) including period appropriate furniture - even including a foot-pump Singer sewing machine.

title: Once you've seen one old district, you've seen 'em all.
content: Bit repetitive, long leafy lanes and then come across a few shops, artists and coffee. Nice for a Sunday morning walk if you have never done it before but look further afield.

title: Probably the best part of Shanghai
content: nice atmosphere with french style houses and trees on the street... there is a bit of the Parisian feeling to it. I recommend to visit it on 2 wheels

title: A reminant of the past
content: I think it was after the Opium wars that European countries took sections of China's cities as their own (i.e. for exploitive trade, exempt from the chinese law). Going to the French Concession was really like stepping back into the long period of European colonialism.

title: Old world charm
content: A good example of the contrasts you find in Shanghai, with a step back into old French style streetscapes and some of the charm that other parts of the increasingly materialistic city has lost.  Good eateries, shopping and wandering to be had.

title: Not super Frenchy
content: The neighborhood definitely had a French/European look, but I expected a overwhelming load of French architecture, which was not there to me. But still very nice to walk around. Expensive neighborhood though.

title: Loved this area
content: You feel like you are in Paris in the middle of Shanghai. With many famous restaurants and even a Belgium beer café this is a great place to visit if you would like a western meal while in China. Very trendy and near the shopping.

title: Most interesting Shanghai neighborhood
content: Shanghai was created as an international city and is much different from other Chinese cities, especially in the former French Concession which still has a European scale to the back streets and buildings and the distinctive London plane trees. A lot of the development of the 1920s and 1930s survived wars and revolutions and there is interesting architecture on the back streets. I've lived here 2 years and keep finding new things.

title: Worth a day trip
content: Great shops, architecture and food definitely worth a visit while in Shanghai! Lots of English language skills in the restaurants and bars which is not a given.

title: Nice Area
content: Each time I travel to Shanghai I visit the Old French area. They have wonderful restaurants and high end shopping. Stop at simply Thai or go to the German Place. (Closed for remodeling this visit)

title: What a nice place to diner in Shanghai.
content: Beautiful traditional architecture, very french part of Shanghai. Here you can find several nice options for diner with friends, hace a cold drink or wine and enjoy company. Beautiful open street bars, modern restaurants with a cosmopolita ambience. Don't forget to visit this place and arrive hungry!

title: Fantastic fusion
content: Superb fashion, architecture and food define this section of Shanghai. We had some fantastic meals here, got a couple of suits made and really enjoyed walking around. Knowing what we know, would have stayed in hotel in the Concession. Maybe next time...

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: One of the most charming areas in SH
content: I am just about moving to Shanghai and I have visited this wonderful area of the city. If my Company's office was not so far from this area I would have considered moving to this place.

title: Go in the afternoon
content:
I went a little to early in the day to appreciate this place. 
Going in the afternoon would have been better because nothing was really open and we just ended up walking around looking at the architecture.

title: Gorgeous charming Shanghai
content: Words you wouldn't usually use to describe Shanghai but this area was a pleasant surprise with narrow streets, cute cafes and boutiques.

title: Great place to walk through
content: Nice quiet place for a walk away from the bustle of the city.  Nice shops, bars and restaurants and interesting old buildings.  Great place for photos.

title: preserved historical area within the city
content: It's too bad more of Shanghai has not been deemed culturally or architecturally significant but thankfully this area has. About 100 years of history from roughly 1850 to 1940 still exist here. So all the buildings are built in the European style and no more than 2 or 3 stories tall. Tree lined streets complete the effect and you feel transported to Europe.

title: Beautiful
content: Fantastic shopping, multiple choices for dining, sensational architecture, equivalent to any luxury occidental town

title: Great photography location
content: It feels as if we are not in China and friends looking at our photos easily mistaken that we are in Europe. However, there's not much to do if you are not looking for food as it is lined with restaurant and not a touristy kind of place. Good for photography though

title: Lovely part of town
content: We visited this area a couple of times during our stay in Shanghai and other than the Bund this was our favourite part of the city. It had a lovely atmosphere in the being to wander through the streets with many International bars and restaurants. It certainly did feel more like France than Shanghai.

title: No historic or architectural interest
content: French Concession was rebuilt with a pure business objective. You will find there luxury and extremely expensive shops with nothing evoking the corresponding period. No worth going there with another objective in mind than expensive shopping.

title: Loads to do in the French Concession.
content:
Love this area for cafe's restaurants and shopping.
This place is great to walk around, sightseeing and just soaking up the best area in Shanghai centre. For me far better to walk around than the Bund.

title: Cozy area with interesting shops and cafes
content: Take your time when discovering the FFC. There are many hidden gems in the many streets including world-class restaurants, indie clothing shops and jewellery makers and all kinds of music and hobby shops you can imagine

title: Fascinating French District
content: Great contrasts in Shanghai. The architecture of the Old French District is well worth walking through

title: A Really Interesting Atmosphere - Architecturally & Culturally
content: For those who are willing to slow down and carefully observe the surroundings, there are great photography opportunities..... For recreation, you can find all kinds of restaurants and shops..... The streets are narrow and lined by beautiful old trees. During times when traffic is not too heavy (Saturday or Sunday mornings before 10am) it is a fun experience to ride bicycles along the streets.

title: Nice way to spend a day...
content: Definite "must-see" area in Shanghai. Quaint colonial style architecture and it's a walk down memory lane.  Now it's filled with a plethora of trendy shops and restaurants.

title: Amazing piece of culture and character oriented in the great of Shanghai
content: Took a day tour with Catherine Lu in Shanghai. Or your guide, David, showed us around the city including the French concession. This is an amazing place in the heart of Shanghai. Lots of little shops, and history right in the central Shanghai.

title: Little French little Chinese
content: This are known as the Former French Concession is a nice part of Shanghai to walk and shop and eat.  I think the architecture is interesting mix of old chinese and western architecture. It's elegant, good designs and good restaurants.

title: A trip back in time
content:
You must visit it when you do Shanghai! Beautiful architecture, independent shops and great restaurants and bars!

That is where the first office of the Communist party was based.

title: Not exactly what we thought..
content: So before we visited Shanghai, we heard a lot about the French Concession area. In my mind I thought it was going to be a couple of streets that were packed full of shops and restaurants, but the area was much more spread out than we realized. And it wasn't exactly marked, so we weren't sure where it started or ended. We did eventually find the right area, but I'm not sure it was worth going out of the way specifically to visit.

title: See a different side of Shanghai
content: Lovely cafes and restaurants in this tree-lined historical section of Shanghai. I hear the brunch is excellent but I didn't get to sample any unfortunately. Well worth a wader and a great place to stop for coffee, lunch (and/or) dinner. Spoilt for choice!

title: Really disappointing.
content: Really disappointing. Nothing to do there appart from big shopping malls. We were expecting it to be like the hipster /trendy district of the city but we didn't even like the restaurants we found there.

title: Yes, a bit of France
content: The little restaurants, the street scene, the architecture all brought a little of France to Shanghai. I love walking the streets in foreign countries, and this is a great place to browse, look for English books in numerous bookstores, eat fantastic foods at little cafes that offer Western and European food, go to beautiful little food markets. It is a quaint and beautiful part of town.

title: I live in this area 3 - 4 months each year.
content: I picked this part of town to live in after many years of living in Shanghai off and on. I go to China for work and travel pleasure. The "former" French Concession has a feel unlike any other part of Shanghai. The tree lined streets create a canopy in the summer that is simply beautiful for walking. There are so many attractions in or near this area that you can stay occupied for days (weeks) exploring the restaurants, bars and shopping. I often take long walks (weather and smog permitting) in this area in both the day and night. there seems to be a special magic in the air to walk here late at night.

title: experiencing french in Shanghai
content: Old French Consession, or called as "Tian Zi Fang" in Chinese, is a great place for you to experience french in Shanghai. Surrounded with high-end boutiques and malls, Tian ZI Fang itself has a lot of cafes & restaurants, art & souvenir stores, and some street food stalls. however, the price of the souvenirs and food are higher than usual. Be sure to bargain when you shop.

title: Cool place to visit
content: Nice neighborhood. Popular with the ex-pats. Some good restaurants and shopping.  Also an area with art galleries. Another great place to spend a half day or more.

title: Quiet and beautiful.
content: This part of the city heralds of the days of imperialism. The buildings are pretty and and the shopping is fair. The restaurants in this area are quite good and a nice mix of Thai, French, and Chinese dining. It's a pleasant place to walk around if you have time, but it's not a must-do if it's your first trip to Shanghai. It is a wonderful place to escape from the crowds.

title: Nostalgia of Old Shanghai
content: South Shaanxi Road Metro Station takes you to the former French Concession. Take a walk on South Maoming Road as well as South Shaanxi Road. As you walk on these two roads, the little shops, small restaurants, tiny residences brings back the nostalgia of Shanghai during the early part of 20th century. The Shikumen houses which are Shanghai's own design of residential houses are found in this neighbourhood.

title: thumbs up
content:
real good elegant area, good for design shops and restaurants!!
the prices are of course not cheap but the designs are definetely good :)

title: Good place
content: We dined nand toured here in Johnny Walker House of walker. Staff were great and the food  was good but very expensive.

title: I could live here
content: I really like the area. Is more European true, with nice bars, restaurants and felt like at home. If I do come back, I would choose a hotel here. Just get lost and walk around the streets. best way to discover.

title: Beautiful part of town
content: Nice little neighbourhood to walk around. Lots of restaurants and cafes, in the summer you can sit outside and people watch. Very peaceful part of town, the alleys are lined with trees, lots of beautiful historic buildings, little shops selling trinkets and souvenirs.

title: the French legacy lives
content: Walking around this area of town offers an overview of the French occupation of Shanghai through the architect they left behind. Grand homes plucked from the French countryside have deteriorated with the advent of the workers take over. One area has been renovated into a shopping area (surprise). While purist mock its fastidiousness, I, as an architect, appreciate the restoration as a set piece of a time gone by.

title: No authenticity
content: This place is way to commercialized and polished to have any authenticity. Bunch of pretentious Chinese people and confused tourists walking around. If your schedule is tight don't bother fitting it in.

title: Quaint part of the city
content: Former French concession is a nice part of Shanghai to take a walk and explore. There's a lot of history but also cafes and restaurants and bars.

title: Where East meets west
content: Allow yourself to linger in the old alleys. The architecture is a very interesting mix of old chinese and western architecture.

title: great shopping area
content: Went twice to the French Concession to shop in the quaint, little stores. Very nice area, fun to walk thru and look at all the little shops. Not as much bargaining here, just pay what they ask. Enjoyed watching them making candy, so had to buy some to take home - very tasty! Starbucks across the street when you get tired, and metro next door.

title: My Favorite Part of Shanghai
content: When visiting Shanghai, do yourself a favor and make a point to visit the Old French Concession.  It's a nice, peaceful neighborhood tucked away from the hustle and bustle of the city.  Nice parks, restaurants and shops.

title: European wine and food in Shanghai
content: It an amazing place with European wine and food available if you are tired of the local meals. Lovely rooftop cafes are absolutely charming.

title: Xintiandi Drop Off
content: If you are heading to the Old French Concession area in Shanghai ask the taxi driver to take you to Xintiandi. He or she will probably drop you off at The Langham Hotel in Xintiandi. There you will be perfectly placed to walk into a safe and pleasant area of galleries, cafes, boutiques and bars and restaurants including such places as Wolfgang Puck restaurant or the Paulander Brauhaus restaurant where you can enjoy two live bands every night. OK, neither restaurants are very Chinese but you can find plenty of local cuisine in the area too. When you want to leave there is a brilliant taxi rank, opposite The Langham, where at night a concierge will ensure you only enter a 'legal' taxi to get you 'home'. In terms of Old French Concession history you can view the Old Shanghai Shikuman housing, also to be seen in the British Concession, and the site of the First National Congress Of The Communist Party Of China. Xintiandi is a great place to visit at any time of day. And just a short walk from one of Shanghai's best shopping streets. Enjoy.

title: Quaint little shops!
content: Loved the small shops selling random items and souvenirs! Felt more local than the many shopping malls in Shanghai. It's not fully sheltered so may not be good to go on a rainy day.

title: Great place for occidental people!
content:
Nice area to walk around, drink, eat and having fun!
Many bar's , nice restaurant and lot of good music like jazz, lounge and dance 
Must go there!!

title: Easy to get lost but well worth getting lost
content: I walk there from my hotel and must have got lost a few time but it is what make its charm. You will eventually find your way in the small street and discovery a more traditional Shanghai. Nice for shopping as well where you need to do a bit of haggling

title: What's all the fuss about?
content: Vent here just to discover it to be an quite average area. Didn't wake any interest in us, but maybe we didn't get something...?

title: interesting part of the city
content: was a nice part of old Shanghai. Interesting to find the 1st meeting place for the Communist party of China. Nice small building with lots of interesting displays about the  communist party

title: unique colonial area, but hard to see most of the buildings
content: I regret not taking a tour.  most of the buildings are obscured by walls.  I would still check it out, it has an international vibe.  lot of restaurants and a few boutique shops.

title: A must of Shanghai
content: Love how this place in the middle of a chinese city makes you feel in Europe for a moment. Great pace to walk around, enter to different stores and maybe seat down, drink a coffee or beer and read for a while.You must visit the museum there to better understand Chinese history in the last century. Entrance to the museum is free.

title: My favorite place to walk in Shanghai
content: Really beautiful are that you cant miss while you visit Shanghai. There are plenty of restaurants and small boutiques.

title: Good architecture blend of old and new
content: Good architecture charming and warm feeling. Much better road than nanjing lu. Can not say the same about the shops as it caters to top end market only. The cafes and cake shops also generally very good

title: Must see
content: I have lived in the French Concession area for 4 years now and love it. The tree lined streets, old architecture, numerous shops, pubs and restaurants make it a must see if you visit Shanghai!

title: Wonderful area to walk around.
content: Allow about 2 hours to justs wander the streets of the French Concession. The area is full of beautiful and historic architecture. One stroll starts at the Xintiandi subway stop, walk along Middle Fuxing Road (All Saint's Church, Park Apartments, crossing Chongquing Rd), through the Sinan Mansions, right on Sinan Rd (Sun Yat Sen's residence), left on Gaolan Rd. (St. Nicholas Church), right on Ruijin, left on Nanchang Rd., right on Maoming Rd. (quipao shops, Cathay Theater) to the Okura Garden Hotel Shanaghai.

title: French concessions
content:
A nice promenade is to be expected in this area, where the French influence of architecture and culture still remains strongly. 
Many trendy shops and cafes have emerged in this area and the ambiance is really nice.

title: Wonderful walk
content: No guided tour here. Just mapped the place out and got to walking. There's a great hidden market back in there that seems endless and crammed with artisans. Go for a stroll.

title: Lovely district
content: Nice area with good vibes. Interesting architecture with lots of independent shops and cosy restaurants.

title: Typical Shanghai of the last century
content: Certainly the most typical quarter of Shanghai from 19th and 20th century still remaining. It is nice to roam in the street without any goal and to have a look at the different architecture of the buildings. Nice atmosphere.

title: Great for a window into the foreign concession time period.
content: Some of the original homes and buildings have been beautifully maintained or restored. This neighborhood provides a great window into life during the foreign concession time. It would be a good place to satay--if the Bund or Pudong is not appealing.

title: LOST
content: I felt lost in Old French Concession. Or i was not sure I was lost or confused. I wasn't feeling Shanghai at that moment. Glad the government decided to keep the French Colonial buildings till today. I loved the atmosphere here. Do drop by for a romantic dinner or quick drink.

title: Lots of great restaurants
content: A little bit of France in China. Beautiful lined streets with lights .Lots of restaurants with reasonable prices .Great coffee as well. Also some boutique shops .could have spent more time there.

title: You can find some of the best street food in the world in this area!
content: You must be selective, but some of the best food anywhere is found in this area.  Take a tour, like one of those from Untour to find the best options!

title: I'm in China really?
content: Felt like I was in France very odd feeling lots of yummy patisseries about and one of the few places with western food shops if u need to stock up. Very pretty area strangely seemed less populated area and the artisan markets a short tube ride away are also a must

title: A historical place
content: If you walk in this area you'll feel something special, the architecture of the house, the streets, the trees...

title: Perfect area for a long walk
content: The combination of old world, new development, and tree lined streets is a great way to spend a solid half day.

title: I can't believe it's China!
content: Very atmospheric place. I liked it a lot, you can buy so many not garbage souvenirs, memory gifts, boho clothes and so many hipster stuff. And you'll never be hungry there 'cause there're so much nice and cozy places to eat with real expat staff!

title: Food fest
content: Some of Shanghai's best restaurants are to be found here! Love Shaanxi Road!! The charm is so beautiful! I can see why this is a desirable community to live in! The bars, restaurants, boutiques, and one of a kind shops are a wonderful assortment of great finds for both shoppers and non-shoppers alike!

title: French Concession - Shanghai
content: The French Concession in Shanghai was a “visual” change with its cobble streets and beautiful western style archways. It is worth an hour strolling through this area.

title: Very interesting
content: A great place to see the real old shanghai with lots of interesting buildings and shopping,  well worth an afternoon strolling around

title: Good for walking
content: if you wish to walk around in shanghai this place should be you first choice, with old french style buildings and some beautiful cafes makes this a perfect spot

title: A QUICK VISIT
content: We had a quick visit in the rain! It looked very pleasant lit up at night but diidn't really find a lot to see and do.

title: Very nice and very expensive
content: We stopped here to get my wife a decent glass of wine, it is a very trendy and modern place, there is free wifi and a Communist museum and plenty of expensive places to eat.

title: Interesting history with European flavour
content: We took a taxi from our hotel to this area which dropped us in front of a Starbucks so first impression not great. However if you walk through the various streets / alley ways you will see architecture from the past that has been restored and a good museum. Most will only see the pedestrian area full of shops and cafes, however there is a walking route that takes in much more (see chinahighlights.com).

title: OH LA LA
content: We loved this area, it's beautiful, has amazing history and great places to eat, lots of young people enjoying life.

title: A welcome pied a marché
content: Find your way to this area where you can walk, sit at a cafe, dine at a boutique restaurant, and people watch. The small alleyways are reminiscent of a time gone by.

title: Great architecture
content: It is a pleasurable walk in the French Concession. Stop by for a coffee and just immerse yourself in the atmosphere of that area.

title: Favourite area
content: It is real Shanghai if you want to see history and architect. It is also full of wining and dining options. It is cool in temperature at summer thanks for French plane trees. Autumn is more beautiful with colourful fallen leaves. It is never boring to walk around for hours or even for days. Must see in Shanghai.

title: Nostalgic
content: Gives you a nostalgic feeling walking down and in between the streets. Does remind me of  Europe in some ways

title: Find Yourself at the French Concession
content: Perhaps this is my favorite area to visit in Shanghai. I love the small restaurants, tree-lined streets and local merchants. The vibe is very western, but has the distinct flavor that only Shanghai can provide. This is a true blend of East and West. I cannot seem to get enough of this warm and beautiful area. Visit D.O.C. for great Italian food, and Abbey Road for a fantastic Bar and Grill!

title: Meander & soak up it's unique blend of architectural style.....
content: Surprisingly, for a place named French Concession, there’s no written French to be found anywhere………. It’s a great vibrant neighborhood and over the course of a 7-day visit to Shanghai during Thanksgiving week, we must’ve crisscrossed the French Concession over a dozen times. Getting to a massage here, and a brewery there……. We even did a cooking school learning to make Shanghai dumpling in this nabe. We enjoyed meandering about its many charming shops and storefront. I especially appreciated some of the old-world architecture that’s unique to this area.

title: Interesting place.
content: Commercial center of Shanghai. A lot of walking. In summer it gets too hot. Subway gets very crowded during rush hour.

title: A little less noise
content: This is a brilliant area if you want to get away from the masses of people and noises for a bit.  Some really great shops and dessert stores. Had the best Macaroons around here.

title: World away from the city
content: With its mix of Victorian and pseudo-classical architecture and throngs of Chinese tourists you could almost be in an actual European city! Seriously though this area is fairly bizarre but actually better than I thought it might be. Despite the fact that it is essentially a pretty well maintained and renovated European-themed zone rather than an active ethnic quarter it has managed to avoid the feeling of being kitsch or plastic and has retained some of the substance of its very interesting past. The cafes and restaurants are nice and it was really quite a relaxing place to eat and spend some time. Surprisingly uncrowded compared to other attractions; you could genuinely almost forget you were bang in the centre of one of the largest cities on earth! Worth a read of the history surrounding it too before you go (assuming you're not already familiar, of course).

title: Fascinating old area - worth meandering through, but avoid holidays and weekends when it can get crowded
content: Lovely old Shanghai. Great buildings - a huge range of shops - plenty of tourist tat and over priced souvenirs. But search in the quieter streets and out of the main areas and you'll find some great corners. Couple of temples worth exploring too. We spent a happy afternoon there.

title: A bit of modern Chinese History
content: We always make a point of visiting this area when in Shanghai. It is just that bit quieter and prettier than the usual bustle of Shanghai. Interesting shops and a great variety of restaurants. We followed a walking tour suggestion and stopped in at the house of Zhou Enlai and the first meeting place of the Communist Party before stopping for a lovely lunch at Old Shanghai Moon in the Jinjiang Hotel, which I believe is where Nixon signed the first trade agreement with China. The tree lined street make this a pleasant walk.

title: Nice example of some old non Chinese Building
content: Quite a few restaurants, some old architecture and it was nice just having a coffee and relaxing and watching the world go by.

title: An oasis in the middle of the city
content: After a 10min taxi ride from the bustling Bund this area was so peaceful and tranquil. Walk from the Propaganda Poster Museum to the Arts and Craft museum to get a taste of this leafy, quaint residential area. Lots of cafes and restaurants in the higher price range but great for a change of pace and cuisine options.

title: Beautiful
content: Calm beautiful part of the city, worth a visit. Those type of old parts of huge cities are usually the nicest to spend time

title: A fabulous place to spend a few hours
content: This is one of my favourite areas in Shanghai. It is always busy so be prepared for a bit hustle and bustle. The architecture is great. There are so many nice cafes and restaurants to eat in and people watch from. There are lots of little shops and stalls and plenty of tourist knick knacks to be had.

title: Unlike the rest of Shanghai
content: This area has tons of restaurants, bars, hotels and shops. Although there are very high end designer shops there are also lots of small shops. This area is popular with the expats.

title: The real Shanghai......
content: The Bund is by all means stunning at night time, but the old part of Shanghai is just great to walk in and take in the sights, sounds and many shops to view. It's the true heart of Shanghai and as you walk you will meet locals and expats who have lived in Shanghai and escaped the concrete jungle New York style Pudong....the beautiful old Shanghai has tree lined streets featuring the odd noodle shop or older cafe where brunch can be enjoyed..........forget Pudong and the jungle.......walk and enjoy the read Shanghai!

title: Dust visit
content: This was lovely but would have been lovely to see before it was dark. Although it has been rebuilt it was still lovely

title: Nice
content: Nice to See. I was there at the Fashion week. So it was really crowded. The Restaurants are a Little bit expensive. But the small streets are really nice.

title: french concession
content: I have been to the old french concession a number of times. the first time was 5 years ago i walked around in the afternoon early evening. this time i walked and rode a bicycle around the area on a couple of separate occasions at all times of the day. it never ceases to amaze me that this place is allowed to exist in such a busy city.

title: Our family lived here during WWII
content: My mother-in-law and her sister-in-law had a shop in the French Concession during WWII during the Japanese occupation and she, her husband and child lived there as well as worked there until they were able to leave Shanghai in 1946. They supported the whole family with their earnings from this one small shop as the men were not allowed to work.

title: Could spend two days exploring this area
content: Romantic, historic, modern and old. This section has something for everyone. Sun Yat Sen residence was closed for rennovation when we travelled. Best to go with guide to navigate and explain.

title: Gorgeous!!!
content: you will love this area. definitely do not miss it. I went with 2 friends and we had the most amazing afternoon we did not want to leave.

title: So Much To See and Experience
content: Regularly listed as a must do attraction, the Former French Concession offers so many dining and shopping options, but that's only the start of the allure.

title: Very interesting area within the huge city
content: It is a pleasure to wander around this area that offers loads to see and stay in European cafés or eat at this type of restaurants.

title: Best area in town
content: This is definitely a MUST SEE in SHANGHAI.  The streets with the trees deliver you a unique oasis of peace in a very busy city.

title: A must see...
content: A very nice place for walking, drinking and having some quality time. Avoid shoping cause that is too expensive, but definitly sit down at a bar or get a massage... this is the place you need to spend your money and enjoy your life.

title: Relaxing
content: A cool concept and a nice way to see some traditional Chinese building however it is not like the rest of mainland China in terms of culture. Plenty of restaurants and bars to watch the world go by.

title: Gentle juxtaposition...possibly interesting the fashion
content: An interesting area of town in that is has a European flair, however, I didn't find it to be that stark of a contrast between the French Concession and other areas in Shanghai. I found myself looking at my map and asking, am I really in the right place? Have I found the French Concession yet?

title: Lovely Afternoon Trip
content: Lovely place to wander around, grab a coffee, people watch, buy some souvenirs or find a bite to eat. Easy to access via public transport using the subway, just get off at Dapuqiao station on Line 9.

title: Trendy and bustling
content: A trendy place to see some of the more contemporary parts of Shanghai and experience some trendy food flavours. A favourite for the ex-pat community

title: An historical place to visit
content: We heard so much about the old French concession that it is a must. Very intersting and quite with many places renovated

title: Surprise find!
content: We decided to stroll around this area and so glad we did! Highly recommend a visit to Tianzifang - a historic residential area full of legacy residential architectures and factories but has now transformed itself into an artsey area full of boutique shops and bars. Also recommend to head

title: Lovely to stroll around
content:
We had been here last night with the fabulous Lost Plate tours and loved the area so strolled back today to wander the streets. Lots of lovely
Little shops and cafes as well as traditional places to eat or snack.

title: A Surprising Pleasing interlude and glimpse of a former Shanghai
content: An interesting place to visit with alleys and architecture of an older Shanghai. It is a little pocket of Paris- Montmartre without a hill in Shanghai with shops and cafes to suit.

title: very modern new european look
content: the place to go to feel the modern european settin.lots of foreigners mixing it up with chinese.pizza,bistros,coffe.looks like a bit of the west.The French concession is worth a stroll among the old buildings and all the new shops. Great place get away from the hustle of Shanghai.

title: Explore the French Old Concession
content: You may have been to Xinitiandi, Tianzifang, or Fuxing park but you have never experienced the French Concession unless you have walked around the Lilongs (alleyways) to see the real life. Ideally buy one of Tess Johnson's books with great walking tours describing the local architectural history. Or as a minimum walk around Cites de Bourgogne on South Shaanxi Road and take a look at the Shikumen houses . Explore all the alleyways you can most are public access.

title: Charming and unexpected
content: It is really unexpected at first to go to this French quarter and have a walk in there, because it definitely is not Chinese-like. But it is fun. And not looking as much as French, more like old Brighton in the UK...

title: A great walk for few hours spent in Shanghai
content: Interesting walking old town district to spend a few hours here. Touristy but in her own charm. Places you can grab a cup of tea or coffee to enjoy an afternoon.

title: Nice to get away from Chinese history for a bit
content: Lined with Old buildings and cobbled lanes with trees on both sides. With all those beautiful gardens and temples that we visit and have come to associate with China and it's culture this was certainly a refreshing change atleast for a little bit. The French concession is very well worth a half day stroll among the old buildings and all the new shops. Great place to feel relaxed from the hustle bustle of Shanghai.

title: You will not believe you are in China
content: This is a lovely and seldomly visited part of Shanghai. Away from the maddening crowds you will be transported to a suburb of France (albeit with Chinese character signs). Streets lined with platanes and chestnuts, small shops, abundant bakeries. What else can you ask for?

title: Fun for a break of temples and gardens
content: China has a lot of beautiful temples and gardens it is fun to stroll through here for a change of pace and scenery. Fun to see a change in architecture and way of life in this pocket.

title: Fabulous Shops & Food!
content: You must go! We are young at heart but over 60 but our kids were able to take us to all the amazing shops down the many narrow streets.We are excited to have the joy of seeing our family enjoying all the ambiance of the old town streets.

title: Good for strolling and browsing
content: Make sure to visit Fu Shing Park on weekends and enjoy the locals enjoying the outdoors and each other. Dancing, singing, discussing, playing and etc. Such a cool thing to just soak up on a nice weekend morning. Get your guidebook and wander a bit. Tankaing Road market winds behind the storefronts (look for umbrellas hanging above the sidewalk signaling the access points). Very fun and goo shopping/drinking and possibly dining.

title: Lanes and old buildings
content:
Best to go early morning to avoid the crowds.
Pretty winding lanes with shops and residences above. It is different from the most recent Shanghai.

title: Lovely tree-lined streets
content: The homes and boutiques along the tree-lined streets of the French Concession were a nice respite from the busy downtown sights.

title: Coffee shops, bars and tree lined street.
content: This is quite a large area nice for walks or bars, most bars close quit early (2200-2300). Nice tree lined streets and lower buildings than in much of Shanghai giving a sense of space. There are lots nice restaurants around dongping road, but you will never be far from a restaurant or coffee shop in the French concessions.

user_loc: 菲律宾马尼拉大都会区
title: Great Architecture
content: Awesome architecture. They really maintained/restored the old buildings. It's a very calming feeling to walk the streets of the former French concession. Just a tip, most of the locals don't call it French concession anymore, I had difficulties asking the hotel and taxi drivers and even my local friends but they don't know where it is. It would be better to research ahead of time before flying to Shanghai since this place is a neighborhood and is huge. You could take a train getting here or grab a cab, you could start by going to Xintiandi, Tianzifang, Fuxing Road, and Huaihai road.

title: Chinese with a French Flair
content: This is the area in Shanghai where I can comfortably live and shop.  I enjoyed stopping for a cup of coffee, a bowl of dumpling soup and a chat with an ex-patriot along the way.

title: Ideal for Saturday Morning or Evening walk
content: We are in Shanghai the second time in five years. Both times we have stayed at a hotel in the French Concession area. We concur with the other reviewers. We love strolling around this area more than doing anything else in Shanghai. There is a lot of small shops - not cheap - and a lot of small restaurants. Yesterdays Halloween night was fun. The place was busting in seems. Restaurans were very busy...A lot of Non Chinese seem to be frequenting this area. My impression is that they are not just tourists, but Shanghai long term residents.

title: So big area not easy to see all of that
content: We saw just a little peace full of restaurant, boutique and very nice little streets, seems to be different from other part of Shanghai

title: A place to visit
content: The magic atmosphere you may experience in this area is unique. The beauty of the full area has been completed by the pedestrian area, fully devoted to shopping and restaurants.

title: Elegant
content: It is amazing how when you come here, you don't feel like your in Shanghai anymore. All the building are very similar. I believe this is more of the wealthy area as I noticed a lot more super cars around this neighborhood than other part of the city in Shanghai.

title: Nice, buzzing area of low rise buildings and western style restaurants
content: Well worth a visit if you are in Shanghai and want to get away from all the modern high rise buildings. Very touristy but great if you want a change from Chinese food as there are very many western style restaurants

title: Walk and walk and walk
content: The French Concession area is large; I know because we walked quite a bit of it. There are of course many European buildings but also Shikumen, wet markets and traditional shops. The small park on Shaoxing Road is lovely. Fuxing Park is fantastic, with its rose gardens and statues of Mark and Engels, and the Chinese singing and exercising. Throw in Zhou En Lai's house (Sun Yat Sen's was closed), the Sinan Mansions, and Fuxing Road, on which we walked to Wukang Road, and you'll get a taste of this area of the city.

title: Tour of China
content: Pretty area with a good selection of cafes and restaurants amid European architecture. Pleasant area in which to walk around and have lunch.

title: The trees......!
content: The trees reminded me of the place in Paris where I stayed before. The shops is just never ending to shop from. There is some petit little Art Studios as well. I visited a little Pottery place where you can make your own little pottery item. There is even Gelato's Ice cream shop. Chinese Tearoom with Cats....real life cats if you are a catlover/person. A must go on your list!!!!

title: A wonderful area for galleries and shopping
content: If you want to spend an afternoon strolling through trendy shops and galleries, this is your spot in Shanghai.  My friend and I spent an entire Saturday perusing artist shops and craft stores.  Really fun.

title: touristy but fun
content: this is a very touristy location, but good fun to spend a couple of hours and go through the chops and cool coffee shops

title: Not what you would expect
content: Nice pretty area with many shops and bars. I would advise a guided tour. Probably bike tour to see more from the area and its history. It is a bit of a shock to see how people still live in conditions that are unthinkable of in Europe. But they all still have the latest mobile technology and some have even got expensive cars. In other words a different kind of priority. Everywhere is clean and although busy still a calm atmosphere.

title: Great Place to Walk and try the local restaurants
content: Very upscale area with gorgeous parks, Plane Trees and great street food.     There are great boutiques.....enjoy this lovely area.   I took a dumpling cooking class here and had a variety of foods on a tour.    You will enjoy.

title: A stroll back in time
content: A pleasant walk in an area built for foreigners.  The streets are tree-lined, the buildings gracious and old, the traffic not so good!

title: best part of the city
content: i live in the french concession. it's the nicest part of the city and a great place to walk around, eat, and explore.

title: old architectures meets nouveau riche
content: Really pretty sights and fancy shops all around. Fusion of old architectures meets nouveau riche types of shops. The rich ousting the poor/middle class out of their homes and neighborhoods because its trendy now.

title: full of small and nice streets
content: nice to walk around the french concession. sometimes feels like europe. beautiful house from the 19th. will recommend during sunny days

title: Great food
content: Great place for food and drinks.

title: Interesting area but lacking French food!
content: Worth a visit but surprised by the lack of French restaurants. We ate at the Greek Taverna which was good value for money and has a rooftop dining area.

title: Western influence in Shanghai
content: Nice to see how the french concession blends in with the epic modern architecture of nowadays Shanghai. There's loads of consulates in this area and some of them are very nice (i.e. the US consulate). Furthermore there's so many bars and restaurants that you won't be hungry for a single moment. Also these venues have a nice blend of Western and Chinese cuisine and everything in between (Thai, Indian etc.) Happily spend hours walking around here.

title: Unmatched expectations
content: Well maybe you expect old houses worth taking a picture of. Yes, there is a few of them, sure. The main area however seems like a huge Turkish bazar, very crowded, very narrow. Perfect for people enjoying shopping, experimenting with food, and being squeezed.

title: Lovely area to wander around
content: Beautiful old buildings mix with modern restaurants, plenty to see & great places to eat. Wonderful place to take pictures.

title: Pretty, a good point of contrast to the rest of Shanghai
content: Its fairly small but has quite a few clubs and restaurants. Expensive though so be aware. Even if you're just walking through its a worthwhile place to visit if just for the contrast with modern Shanghai architecture, it has a pretty interesting history as well so if you're into history, I would look it up a bit beforehand.

title: One of my favourite places in Shanghai
content: Love that feeling when you walk along these narrow streets in Shanghai. Still remember the time when I used to work in a tall office building on Weihai road and in the morning after getting off the subway I had to pass through this district. It is so amazing to watch people's life there: it is an incredible mix of cultures, centuries and generations. Take subway and get off at Nanjing East Road station and then...just walk and watch.:) it is really a pity that many of those buildings have been recently destroyed, so catch the time to see a real old Shanghai....absolutely love it!

title: Shanghai French Concession
content: By the time we got here ... I was just about " history' d out" and internally screaming for something " normal" ... The tour guide left us here for a few hours and we wandered around then sat and had cocktails and French fries and watched the world go by... It recharged my batteries. Planning to return to Shanghai to stay in the French Concession to explore this beautiful place further.

title: French Shanghai
content: The French Concession is a very exclusive are to be in with wonderful old buildings, clean tidy streets with easy access, and a lot of history. A very safe area with a very good feel to it. We enjoyed our walk very much

title: Great afternoon walk
content: In my experience the best way to experience the old french concession is to take a walk around, have a coffee somewhere, maybe a bite to eat.

title: History life
content: Hundred years back, the concessions were the most important part of Shanghai, the reacts are still vivid, not only the alleys with old trees - I love - of the French concession but also many buildings from that time, giving a special atmosphere, not so much the modern high rises buildings. Walking through the roads I found - and you may also see - many small colorful shops, boutiques, and whatsoever more. It is a life inside a history of Shangai, really worth to see as a tourist!

title: Tidy and wide range of shopping
content: Liked the tidiness of buildings around. Much cleaner I suppose. Many different choices of restaurant around. Shopping is convenient, whether it's high fashion brand or local designer.

title: A Different Looking Shanghai
content: When you walk through the French Concession it's hard to believe that you are in China. The architecture is very European and the area is filled with "Western" restaurants, such as Wolfgang Puck and a lot of trendy and expensive shops. It can be a nice escape from Chinese cuisine, but expect to pay a little more!

title: if you are looking for nice quite tour experience...
content: one of my favorite places in Shanghai, reminds me of my visit to France. worth to spend afternoon and walk around, find some hidden quite cafe place. wonderful!

title: Beautiful but very Western
content: A beautiful place to come, if you are a little homesick. The range of restaurant, bars and shops is vast and you will easily find something to whet your appetite if you do not feel up to Chinese for a night.

title: Ferguson Lane on Wukang Road
content: It took me a while to figure out where to walk in the old French concession for 2 hours. I grew up in Shanghai in the 70-80s and my grandparents had lived here all their life in this area. My starting point was Hengshan hotel and I went to see the old quarter of my childhood memory. Some parts have changed, but a lot still remained. The streets in this part of the town are lined with big leafy tall tree as they always were. Wukang road is a must, it has a few grand residences from former times, such as the former Italian consulate residence. The highlight is the Fergerson Lane (establishement, not a street) with 10-20 boutique European restaurants inside a big garden house. Anyone would love this find. Continue along on this street to Anfu road ( dotted with a lot of boutique shops, restaurants as well as renovation sites). I am sure you will find more interesting places strolling around in this area.

title: you'll even hear a bit of french
content: It's a bit difficult to know exactly where the French Concession is located as it's a bit spread out and much has been replaced by high rise condos with hilarious names (Richgate Estates for example). Watch for the mat black lamborgini creeping along in traffic. I'm pretty sure he goes through a clutch every month.

title: A different look to Shanghai. Wonderful.
content: You feel like in Europe, small houses, gardens, nice shops. A nice way to forget the crowded Bund. Just walk in the small roads and look at the hidden restaurants.

title: A lovely place to visit and also to see the old style architecture.
content: Easy to get to on the Metro. If you like shopping , this area has trendy shops, art studios and also cute and quirky bars in the old traditional alley ways. There are also cafes to eat at as well.

title: Has great looking buildings!
content: I taught in a school within the French Concession for 2 weeks during the summer. I suggest that the best subway stop to easily get around the French Concession is West Nanjing Road as the public transport after that I have found can be a little bit spotty!

title: Quaint
content: The buildings and setting of this area are beautiful, but a visitor from the UK it felt a bit strange being in China and looking at French buildings

title: A little Western retreat!
content: This is a must visit place if you want a little Western World in China. We were in China for over a week and took a cab ride to the French Concessions one afternoon, it was a wonderful and refreshing break in the vacation. Absolutely beautiful!!! We love people watching and it is a great place to sit and sip on Red wine and watch people!

title: The "detail" that makes the town perfect
content: Because nothing should miss in Shanghai, this place got even the "old French Concession". Not only you live in a wonderful megapolis, but you have even the pleasure to spend your days ( if you live there ) in small houses, with some little garden, little shops that produce a wonderful cultural mix between Europe and China

title: A nice little area with shops and some restaurant/bars
content: I didn't know what to expect from this area. It is in fact like the other reviews online. It feels like a little French town due to the way the shops and restaurants are set up.

user_loc: 卡罗莱纳州亨德森维尔
title: A quieter area to walk in.
content: The streets are winding with some lovely older homes and alleyways that open up into trendy little shops and restaurants.

title: Don't forget the French Concession!
content: Very fun place to stroll!  We took the Ho-Ho bus and disembarked to walk around...found a lovely little restaurant to have lunch (Ciest La Vie)...the best pizza and service!

title: Nice small alleys and architecture
content: Its nice to stroll down the small alleys and see the European (French) architecture. It does indeed remind one of some streets in France. The area is quite big and includes different areas both larger/better accessible ones with different architecture style buildings/villas as well as small alleys with boutiques/shops that sell 1001 different things. If you haven't been to or don't live in France or just want a quick getaway from the busy life in Shanghai this might be a good way to spend your day.

title: Very pleasant and historical area.
content: Loads of atmosphere in this tree-lined street area.  No shortage of nice restaurants.  A nice area for a relaxing walk.

title: Nice but crowded
content: Came to visit on a tour. The area is nice and it feels as if you are not in china but somewhere in france. The buildings are well restored and the cafes and restaurants had a great atmosphere. We came on one of the busy holiday week for china and people were everywhere. The area was fully packed and the smell of cigarette smoke was enough to make me feel dizzy. Chinese people love their ciggies and dont care for public places. It ruined the place for me.

title: Great place!
content: From the moment you see the lane with the trees, you feel that you are in France. Many old France buildings, combined with new ones and its shops.

title: Old French Concession is Great
content: The Old French Concession is the place for sights and sounds, especially if you live here and you want some connection to back home. From the finest in western nightlife, such as the Kung Fu Comedy Club, to historic homes of once famous figures in Chinese history, such as Sun Yat-sen, the Old French Concession delivers it.

title: A very different side of Shanghai
content: We rode bikes around this area as my friend lives here and I can totally understand why. Real old European elegance with beautiful tree lined streets and great restaurants and bakeries. Very flat so the best way to really experience it is by bike and the Chinese cope very well with all the bikes on the rode I never felt unsafe.

title: Interesting but spread out
content: Interesting area but not a lot to see or do.  Big area and very spread out.  If there are more interesting places here they were hard to find, and I was with someone local.

title: Didn't like it that much
content: The are some nice stores, cafes and bares in the area and some interesting buildings but most of them aren't on the best shape. And the stores and cafes are very spread apart.

title: Quiet area of Shanghai
content: This area of Shanghai is very different than the main tourist areas like the Bund.Lots of little Museums.Tree lined,very interesting architectures.Lots of Foreign Embasseys located here and I think this is the top residential location for foreigners.

title: An interesting place to explore
content: You will probably not need to spend much time here walking the street. Pretty interesting to walk about and you do find many cafes and restaurants here.

title: Escape to the past in heart of major city
content: An escape back to the Colonial past in the heart of a modern city . For Architecture buffs , history buffs ,and Historic  Chinese sites buffs .

title: hidden gem in Shanghai
content: Had a blast here, lots of cool things in such a busy city. If your tired of the crazyness of Shanghai, take a stroll here.

title: Lovingly restored
content: A really attractive area, with lots of restaurants and small businesses in new buildings constructed in the original style.

title: Great area for a walk
content: This area is a lovely place for a stroll. Most streets are tree lined with London planes giving them shade. There are tons of restaurants, bars, and interesting shops along these streets. We spent an afternoon wandering the area, had lunch, plus deep fried sesame balls, did a little shopping, all while marveling at the trees and architecture. It helped that it was a beautiful late summer day with a nice breeze and sun.

title: A must do
content: Visited the French Concession area of Shanghai. Lovely shops, bars and restaurants. Also plenty to see from modern to old. Good for both daytime and evening. Recommended.

title: Amalgamation of Asian and European Architecture !
content: On our recent trip to Shanghai we were passing through this region where you will find many villas of old French architecture interspersed with some Chinese model buildings ! The streets have tall trees on either sides making it a nice avenue ! Dr.K.Sundar , Dubai .

title: Not worth it
content: This was an old French developed area.  Now it is just a walk way with many restaurants.  Not worth the trouble, as there is not much to see.

title: Magical to walk around here for a day or half day
content: Definitely find your way here and spend half a day getting lost in the beautiful tree lined streets.  Some places more touristy than others and appreciate the touristy spots for what they are.

title: Architecture to be seen, expensive shops to avoid!
content: The architecture is interesting, especially in contrast to the modern city sprouting all around it. The drawback is the incredible prices being asked in the designer shops and cafes to be seen in.

title: European style!
content: if you suddenly miss Europe, this is the place to go, with its beautiful cafes European style, and that international atmosphere.

title: Quaint but touristy
content: Not that there is anything wrong with being touristy, but if you are coming here to experience the 'old' Shanghai, you're about a century to late. But this is definitely worth a visit. Rambling the back alleys with shops alternating between unique boutiques and tourist kitsch it s pleasant way to spend an afternoon.

title: Beautiful French Quarter
content: Walking through the French Concession is like strolling through the West Village in Manhattan.  If is beautiful, eclectic, and bohemian.  Many Western faces will great you. There are many restaurant choices, ice cream, and interesting shopping.  Go there you won't be disappointed!

title: Heng Shan Rd
content: I lived in this area from 2006 to 2008 and visit every time I return to Shanghai. Many worthwhile restaurants and bars in this area, All in a short walk and convenient to Metro line 2.Sasha's is a great place, across from Shanghai Brewing Co. I'd also recommend Cotton's, a little off Heng Shan - take Yong Jia Rd a short block to Anting Rd, then one block. Many others along Heng Shan Rd and one block each side - too many to mention. Not a food street, but a whole district.

title: The place to go to be seen - if that's what you want!!!
content: A bit over-rated. It's just an upmarket restaurant and bar area .Frequented by the new Yuppies. Looks like a poor attempt to re-create Le Marais.

title: Old world charm with a twist
content: International flavors and a vibrant night life. Don't miss the Old Manhatten Club and a walk in the neighborhood.

title: A gem
content: An  example of very high quality refurbishment of a beautiful but previously shabby and faded historic quarter. This is high-end Shanghai with star name restaurants (e.g. Wolfgang Puck) and lovely shops. Not to be missed.

title: I absolutely love this area of ShangHai
content: There is so much to see, so many cool little restaurants and hotels. All very affordable and top notch entertainment. On a return visit, this WILL BE the area I will spend the most time in.

title: Lovely place
content: A thought I had when walking down the street was that I am no longer in Shanghai but in Western Europe. The streets are mostly quiet, two to three stories shop houses lined with hipster brunch places, bars, restaurants and stores. Shops here would mostly carry menus in English. You can easily spend an entire day exploring the lanes on your own.

title: Loely spot to eat
content: Felt like stepping back to a western trendy district. Lots of eateries and lovely quaint shops. realy interesting that this is in Shanghai.

title: Criticism of reviews
content: I'm giving this a 4 review mostly because the other reviews have been so unhelpful. We enjoyed the experience by starting at fuxing park, which had a nice rose garden, several senior singing and dancing groups and interesting historical sites, including the Marx and Engels statues Exiting the park on the east we passed a few closed coffee shops, walked in the Sun Yat Sen residence, which was a great museum. At that point we walked down fujian road north toward the intercontinental. We had a cool experience, but feel we missed a few of the more interesting roads and shops.

title: Pleasant area
content:
Not all that different from the British sector to look at, but a few more European restaurants.

We didn't eat here as we had an appointment to eat local food elsewhere.

Worth a look to get an insight into the development of Shanghai.

title: Good walk and Relaxing
content: There is nothing much I did rather than walking around the buildings with friends. There are some nice coffee shops to enjoy a quality cup of coffee while relaxing. Neighbourhood is very busy but in french confession people could have their own moments. If you are on a short trip it is not worth going according to my point of view.

title: Xiantandi
content: Refer to this as Xiantandi as no-one seems to know it as the French Concession. Delightful area of Shanghai. Clean and green.

title: A nice walk
content: I followed one of the routes outlined in a travel book.  The old streets and buildings can really take you back.

title: Nice walk!
content: It is a nice neighborhood to walk around and have a meal. There are more places where english is spoked and more foreigners as well. There are major brands stores and luxury stores as well. The Fuxing Park (with locals doing their activities such as Tai Chi Chuan, playing cards, exercising, dancing, etc) would be a great start for this walk.

title: Good food choices expensive shops
content: Nice to see with lots of restaurants and bars good place to eat certainly if you've had your fill of Chinese food. The shops around the area are mega expensive in my view. The actual area does not feel as French as the title suggests which is more a matter of legacy rather than current set up.

title: trendy vibe
content: Nice place for a long brunch on a Sunday. Very trendy modern area with shops and restaurants - though you could be anywhere in the world.

title: Worth a Stroll. Not a Must See.
content: This area has a number of shops and a large number of restaurants. The architecture is interesting and worth a visit. However, if rushed, definitely not a must see in my book of travels.

title: French concession/Xintiandi
content: Plenty of nice restaurants & Malls, good location to spend time & have dinner. Tried the yunan restaurant in one of the Malls, great food.

title: Cute place, nothing special
content:
If it weren't for the construction noise it would have been a great place to relax and have brunch.

It was nice, I liked it, but it didn't impress.

user_loc: 澳大利亚大墨尔本地区
title: Quite & Amazing area. Peaceful & great restaurants
content: This is a charming area to wander through, as you can see the change in architecture and style of surroundings. We heard good things about the area & were not disappointed !! There are a lot of shops and a number of good restaurants that were crowded which was good to see!!

title: Certainly worth going to
content: Hengshan restaurant, go there. Nice area, some beautiful parks and older houses and pubs. Definitely worth going to.

title: Alfresco Dining...away from the crowd
content: An area ideal for high end shopping & alfresco dining...One can still see buildings remnants of the "french" old days. A place of cute little shops filled with souvenirs & different "gifts" to be given out to friends & love ones back home. A drink or two is a must in one of the restaurants...people watching to kill the time...

title: French Maybe!
content: Very small modernised area with some nice restaurants serving wine and western food.  Could be anywhere, being on a tour I can't be sure about 'historic' buildings.  If you miss it don't  fret, just another cup of coffee on the way to somewhere else.

title: Shanghai's Pearl
content: Lots of small and interesting streets. Not all are full of shops, but there are plenty of old buildings, locals and tourists with character. Streets like Fuxing Lu, Wuyuan Lu, Anfu have plenty of leafy trees, cafes, quiet laneways, interesting shops, old houses, former leaders' residences and just a bit of the local traffic chaos, of course. The area is really historical and unique in the Shanghai sense. Take a camera and visit during Spring, Summer or Autumn, while everything is at its' greenest.

title: The Quietest spot in Shanghai !
content: It was raining the day we visited so only briefly but very pretty area with cafes tucked away in little streets, if you are from Australia this reminds us of Melbourne a lot, leafy and pretty.

title: Incredible world neighborhood
content: Charming, beautiful, and quiet.Cozy bars and excellent food. Would happily stay in this neighborhood my next trip to Shanghai.

title: Peaceful Place
content: It doesnt look like you are in china at all. Except for the granpa and grandmas riding their electric bike here and there.

title: Very divers!
content: Really amazing area houses eateries and restaurants by the dozens.  Terrific architecture and deep history.  An afternoon will want you to continue to come back for more.

title: Charming
content: This is a charming area to wander through, as you can see the change in architecture and style of surroundings. We wandered the streets for a good part of the day. There is a lot of shopping and some street vendors/resturants. We went to Boxing Cat Brewery ( there are 3 locations but the one in French Concession has the most charm & good vibes) Overall, great area to go stroll on a day, especially with all the mature trees!

title: It is okay
content: Just street with buildings built by the French people, some bars, and restaurants as well. Nice place to hang out with friends

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Worth a stroll but not a must see
content: I found the old french Concession to be over rated. It was a pleasant morning of strolling around, but I travelled to china to see China, not to walk around one of the most European feeling parts of the country! It also lacks the vibrancy of other parts of Shanghai. Worth a stroll but not a must see.

title: Buildings around you can see are spectacular...every one, one different architectonichal style. Really impressive!!!
content: It's one of the main places to visit when you are in Shanghai. One of the 3 hearts of the city. Plenty of people, always...365 days per year. Also, you can have a nice walk until Bund or Xian Tian Di, that can complete the visit to this part of Shanghai.

title: Very characteristic
content: Enjoyed chilling out after a visit to the museum. After days of being taken to really mediocre  Chinese places to eat by a tour leader we enjoyed chilling out in this very western quarter.

title: French quarter Shanghai
content: Huge area containing lovely old style architecture meeting modern Shanghai , recommend tianzifang and Xintiandi as two good (but quite touristy) shopping areas

title: nice old quarter
content: to take time to feel the old shanghai by walking in this little streets which are reduced to a trickle

title: Trying out living in Shanghai
content: I stayed at an Airbnb in the French Consession and it was a great place for a foreigner to stay.  Lots of expats there an many restaurants and bars were foreigner friendly!

title: Favorite Part - Anfu Lu & Wukang Lu
content: My favorite parts are Aufu Lu and Wukang Lu, calm, charm and many small shops and eating / drinking opportunities, very clean streets with tall trees. Take a seat at a coffee shop or bar and watch as the tourists and locals meander by, have great laugh with friends and relax.

title: Must visit
content: Along with the bund this is the must visit. Even if you are in shanghai for 1 day. 2 apple stores nearby.

title: Nice stroll
content: Somewhat hard to locate the exact area. We asked at our hotel and took a cab but still ended up several blocks from where we needed to be. Pleasant stroll around dinner time with several restaurants nearby.

title: A Must Visit!
content: Great way to spend quite a few hours. Wander around the little stores, enjoy some amazing food, take photos, and just enjoy Shanghai. Lots of really interesting little stores. Perfect place to buy a really lovely quality souvenir or gift, if that's what you are looking for. Loved this area a lot! Also would be a nice area to stay in.

user_loc: 新西兰奥克兰中心地区
title: Quaint and modern historical area
content: This historical area that has been fully restored has retained all the charm of yesteryear but with modern amenities. It

title: Newman Tours are great to tour The French Concession
content: Did a tour here with Newman Tours which was great even the locals got involved and shared their stories. Daniel make this a really informative and interactive session and fun to learn about the history of the area. I highly recommend that you see this area before you leave Shanghai and see the European influence of the area from the late 19th and early 20th Centuries.

title: Eclectic and vibrant
content: A great spot! Walk amongst the old lanes crowded with shops and restaurants of all types and budgets. From quirky to souvenir, from young to designer hip tea sellers, this is a great way to shop or just wander. Think Harajuku meets the Left Bank meets Hoi An, meets Newtown/St Kilda and you get the sense. It's a Chinese version and fascinating as a result. Historic architecture and contemporary Chinese young designers - it's great!

title: Loved the eating spots and general vibe of the old French Concession
content: Easily accessible by metro this is a really interesting place with some wonderful restaurants and art galleries. Some more history to be had

title: So glad that some of old Shanghai still exists!
content: With all the rapid redevelopment of Shanghai, with the demise of its history and the emergence of a 60+ storey metropolis, it is nice to see an area of the city that symbolises the past. Wander through the streets and their French-influenced buildings, and put the Shanghai Propaganda Poster Art Centre at 868 Huashan Road on your agenda to make it even more worthwhile.

title: Old French Concession
content: Really enjoyed this part of Shanghai. Lots of fantastic restaurants and trendy shops and interesting people. Felt safe and lots of style all around and had Italian food.

title: Europe in Shanghai
content: If you want to see something very nice, you have to visit French Concession. Very nice part of the town, where you can find European bars, restaurants etc.

title: Very classy but very expensive
content: A very exclusive and pretty area to visit. Take your wallet and your own toilet paper as you have to in China

title: A little French Fancy!
content: This is a lovely chance to take a trip back in time to what the old colonial French quarter was like. This whole site has been renovated and is calm, beautiful and has many shops and eating / drinking opportunities. The actual layout of the site makes it cool in the summertime and it is all kept very clean and no garbage on the streets. This is such a contrast to the huge skyscrapers literally just along the road.

title: Old Europe in the heart of Shanghai
content: The French Concession is like being in Europe. The restaurants are awesome and the hotels are cheap and clean. A safe and low cost area of Shanghai with the transit nearby.

title: Nice place to explore and sit and people watch
content: This is a lovely area to explore, see all the lovely buildings and shops.  It's also a nice place to grab a drink and or a snack and sit and watch the world go by.

title: Oasis in a busy city
content: We greatly enjoyed walking through the FCC and loved that there were fewer car horns here, and less direct sun due to the trees lining the roads. The sidewalks also seem wider here. We ate at LaVite and Coconut Paradise in the FCC and highly recommend them to anyone looking for some 'western' food.

title: French style and a Chinese life
content: This is one of the most intriguing quarters in Shanghai. A combination of French artistic style with a Chinese life. Walking around the area you will see lots of beautiful clothing shops with an odd great restaurant and a park. Worth taking a few hours to have a small walk admiring this quarter, rather that rush through.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚卡尔斯巴德
title: nice for a short walk, would not linger
content: Beautiful shops and restored alleyways.  The tree lined streets are lovely and certainly a testimony to the history of the past 100 years.  However, the shops are largely foreign luxury stores.

title: love it
content: very nice area. It gets you a chance to see the local life and enjoy the nice surroundings. A must see

title: Nice atmosphere
content: I really love the vibe of Old French Concession. Stroll around the little houses, look into the little shops and litte cafes and have a drink.

title: Historical legacy
content: This place is characterised with tree -lined streets and old villas without the typical people crush in Shanghai.
