content: If you go to shanghai the old french concession is a must. Best to have a map or find an online walking tour to get all the hidden treasures in. There are plenty if places to have a coffee or something harder, or just do a bit of shopping and look at the old architecture. If I had the chance to explore anywhere in shanghai more it would be this area

title: to visit
content: nice place to visit with some few boutiques, a bakery, and a tea shop,

title: it is everything you read about only 10x better
content: it is not possible to really write a comprehensive review on the best neighborhood on one of the most amazing and ever evolving city in the world. as a chinese american who had a good fortune to have lived in the middle of French concession for a year as an expat for my company, I'd say if you come to Shanghai, spend a good amount of your free time just walking around in this neigjborhood. ... you'd be thoroughly impressed. I am, every year when I come back for the past 10+ years. there is always something new, exiting, chic, well-appointed, fun .. that you won't find in NYC, Paris, Berlin, Milano, Rome, Venice, London, HK, Tokyo. it is 1) beautiful .. most streets are cozy lanes lined with dense canopy of these "French" trees (possibly sycamore? I am not sure but I see them all the time in Provence and Italy) 2) completely walkable .. it is like Paris (where I have walked all over every time I go), streets are cozy and pretty, lined up with some of most chic, creative, unique boutique stores. 3) filled with cafes, restaurants where most staff speak basic English. you'll find anything you palate desires .......down to earth chinese tapas, best hamburgers, pasta, pizza, to IPAs. 4) I love window shopping in Paris because of the decor, the interior design, and window display. but it is safe and fair to day SH nowadays beats Paris out of water. if you are the kind that appreciates great merchandising and design (which I do), come to SH, esp French concession, you'll see some of the best examples in the world. 5) filled with people from all over. you'd hear French, German more often than chinese sometimes. French concession, actually city of SH overall, is a prime example how far China has come along, and what I would like to see the majority of China to become ... needless to say, SH is NOT China. SH is SH, an amazing city where you'll have a lot of fun.

title: Great, provided you have cash...
content: It's a nice little area, but don't bother going if you're a traveller on a budget. All the shops and restaurants are upmarket, expensive places (even for Shanghai), and it'll be a waste of your time.

title: nice place to walk and see
content: small stores with local high end art and great tea houses, cafes and restaurants. You can walk around and among other chinese tourist who come from province to see this place.

title: Great place to bargin and walk around
content: The old section of the Frenc Concession is a fantastic place to eat, walk aorund and shop - great bargins and quant shops. A must go!

title: What was so special about this area?
content: Maybe I missed something, but I didn't think this area was as Awesome as everyone has said. I went during lunch time, had an average lunch at a crowded japanese restaurant. There were old buildings but I honestly didn't see what was the big deal about the French Concession.

title: Cosy area
content: If you have time you should definitely drop by, lots of nice places. I had dinner at a place called Lost Heaven, really nice place.

title: A taste of France in Shanghai
content: We walked around this area at night and there were lots of outdoor cafes and people enjoying the French ambience over a glass of wine or beer. Had we had more time we would probably have had dinner there. The prices were reasonable and it would make a nice change in ones diet. You would swear you were in a small square or streetcape in Paris. It is very pretty at night and charming besdides.

title: Pretty Area
content: This is a refurbished area with high end stores and restaurants. If you are missing some of the comforts of home, this is a good place to go for dinner or a coffee.

title: Maybe we missed the good bits?
content: Disappointing. We felt like we were in a dirtier part of the city. The streets were clogged with a different pollution to that in the Jian 'an area. We walked enough to find more up market areas but somehow it still felt grubby. We had expected something of a coffee bar culture - found a working city.

title: A different world!
content: Loose the preconcepions about Shanghai, especially when you visit this unique neighborhood. Influences from a previous era abound here. Fun to simply walk around.

title: great for a stroll
content: make sure you go into the smaller lilong house areas. and take your guidebook so you get to see some of the older buildings and hotels. Some trendy shops and 'lifestyle stores' have opened in the area, which can be pricey but are worth popping in to. including Green and Safe cafe/grocer.

title: Fantastic nightlife
content: This place needs to be seen in the day for the beautiful French architecture of the buildings and in the night for the excellent night life and dining/pubbing options that it offers. Must visit place in Shanghai!

title: Who planted the TREES?
content: What a contrast to modern Cement China. Such a pleasure to walk its many tree lines streets and dip into the lane houses and back streets. I have wandered around for a couple of months and found different routes each weekend. Lots of surprises from little specialty shops to rows of tailoring shops to, would not mind renting that house, to good beer or wine stops, to all manner of eateries, to Foreigner hang outs worth avoiding, to families living on top of each other in the lanes as if Shanghai did not exist,.slaughtering chickens, buying veggie from blue plastic bags randomly presented on the road while a group plays cards on a wooden box fags burning for no reason.

title: Cotton pub is a cosy little house for drinks and dinner
content: Pleasantly surprised to visit through friends recommendation at xinhwa Road. Almost missed it, due to recess from main road. Old building, with warm genuine fireplace. The place quickly filled up with patrons for dinner and very busy.

title: If I lived in Shanghai I'd live here
content: Great place to get lost, and could easily wander around these low rise streets fir days. Plenty of great places to eat.

title: The architecture of the buildings!
content: This is a cool area and my favorite part of Puxi. I really like the area near Heng Shan Lu. I think the roads are a bit small, but other than that it's nice with many cool shops and restaurants!

title: Romantic Shanghai
content: A must when visiting Shanghai. This is the other face of a business metropolis. Romantic, green and with all kinds of shops. No skyscrapers here! Just enjoy a little bit of French colonial style in China!

title: Don't miss the French concession
content: Apart from strolling around the tree-lined streets and admiring the colonial houses and art galleries, a good way to see the old French concession is to book a tour that includes Dr Sun Yat Sen's mansion (which is in the concession). We took a tour from our hotel that covered the mansion and one or two other interesting sights, including the interesting museum of Arts and Crafts (Fenyan Road) where you can see artists and craftspeople at work.

title: Enjoyed taking a stroll through the tree-lined streets
content: This is the part of Shanghai which still has trees lining streets and the buildings are only 3 stories high. I think this must be the most desirable place to live. Check out Xintiandi and see the upscale remodeling of the Shikumen houses. The restaurants look like you should be in Palo Alto. Tianzifang was much more bohemian and I liked it a little more. If you are a history buff you can see SunYatSen's house and CCP house.

title: So much like Paris
content: The only place in Shanghai with tree lined blocks. The architecture reminds everyone of Paris, and plenty of food options. Try the Pancake house.

title: OOh La La
content: The French Concession is lovely. A quiet oasis in very hectic Shanghai. Lots of refurbished historic buildings, beautiful cobbled streets and alleyways. Speciality shopping and plenty of character. Restaurant and cafes good too. Lots of art galleries.

title: La concession française de Shanghaï
content: Trendy place with both tourists and expats. This part of Shanghai have som of the finest residential buildings and streets. Get your bike and start exploring.

title: Fantastic
content: This area is really nice and beautiful. It looks so lovely, all the little alleys, shops, bars. Definitely go there!

title: Great visit!
content: This is another must in Shanghai. Shows some of the history of the city and its culture over the last century.

title: You don't have to be French
content: Great area with great restaurants, shops, even an Italian Gelato shop. The buildings are mainly smaller and there is a real Chinese street life going on around you. This is not the 4 Seasons, or Hyatt type atmosphere. It's better.

title: The hidden gems
content: No tourist. Quiet and laid back neighbourhood. You can peep into the small alleys to get a feel of the local life. Tree-lined winding streets with old style bungalows built in the 20s and 30s scattered around the area.

title: Where the nightlife is!
content: We came here on a Friday, and at 5pm in the afternoon, people gather here to get some drinks and have a good time. We even saw 2 Ferrari and Lamborghini cars parked in the area! However, on our part, we only fed our eyes with the nicely preserved Xin Tian Di and Tian Zi Fang, walked around the vicinity and took photographs. This is also the birthplace of the Communist Party.

title: Wendy Wu Tour
content: This was quite different to what we had been seeing in Shanghai. This is very European designs with quiet surroundings and trees, and you saw many Europeans in this area. Had a coffee here, some places would be expensive to dine in ,in contrast to other Chinese restaurants.Worth a visit.

title: Xintiandi!
content: After being in China for more than 2 weeks, we really appreciated visiting a place where Europe, meets China in a very cosmopolitan way. We enjoyed the restored french style building and the taste of fusion food. I see many people complaining in travel forums, about how this is is not the real China. But for me, it is a MUST. It was a perfect place to go relax after a long days work and experience cafe style, bistro and bar/rest with great ambiance and beautiful people from all over the world.

title: Historical site preserved for restaurants and retail . . .
content: Typical of any city, this is an old preserved area, updated with modern retail shops, restaurants and pubs. But, all good fun, with interesting architecture - buildings from the colonial era. Interestingly different from the rest of China, where old buildings tend to be characteristically Chinese and very old, the ones here have a European colonial feel.

title: The former French Concession in Shanghai
content: Shanghai French Concession is located in Xiuhui and Luwan districts. It is the earliest, largest and most prosperous among the four French Concessions in China from 1849 until to 1946. With the politics, shopping and dining, the entertainment is guarantee here. The Shanghai French Concession is a must-see for tourists.

title: Unique and inviting
content: We visited this area at night and it was just beautiful. Wander around the alleys comprising shops, bars and restaurants and soak up the atmosphere. Shanghai is very cosmopolitan compared to the rest of China and this area is testimony to that.

title: Cutest place ever
content: I wished I could stay here more time, I visited in the night and if was lively and lovely. I wanted to stay on all bars to enjoy the music and the scenary

title: move along, nothing to see here
content: Don't waste your time. There's nothing remotely interesting about this area. It's already faded from memory.

title: Chinese dress boutiques on South Mao Min Road
content: As many wrote, a great place for walking tours. If you are interested in getting a Chinese dress (both contemporary and old-style), go to Mao Min Nan Lu, or South Mao Min Street. A series of boutiques will welcome you. Shanghai Tang has a shop there. So does Leaves Fashion, or Jin Zhi Yu Ye. Both sell high-quality Chinese-style contemporary dresses for men and women. You can buy western brand goods at shops on one of the major streets, Huahai Road. Old French style houses are on backstreets, including Sun Yat Sen’s former residence, which is now a museum. Most houses in the area are lived by ordinary Chinese people. Hanged washing clothes make me smile.

title: Cosmopolitan space in the city
content: This was a very interesting walk - eclectic shops and restaurants, a clear international flavor. Architecture differs here, with a calming quiet feel. A fun day to explore artsy shops, with low key "sales" approach, but willing to bargain for prices.

title: lovely street
content: just like the french cafes outside.expensive and busy. looked like some nice shopping streets ajsent but didnt have any spare time

title: Foody Paradise
content: Although relatively modern it seems much older. Lots and lots of Chinese eating places where you can watch and eat the dumplings. Some of the food smells are "unusual" to the Western nose.

title: Amazing......Give me a break!!
content: OK. The missus and I were spoiled in the French Concession as our son lives there. Notwithstanding. We were treated to the most outstanding restaurants (slash/venues) one could wish for in this quarter. The fashionable dress for European men these days is: long sleeve shirt (sleeves rolled up) fashionable shorts and thongs....yes thongs. Don't feel uncomfortable, guys...this is the SHANGHAI fashion!!!

title: charming place for a walk
content: It is a great neighbourhood to go for a walk in. There are boutiques, restaurants and cafes as well as homes, parks and schools. Get off the subway and then walk until you want a snack. The next subway stop is luckily always nearby to take you back home.

title: experience for everyone!
content: Lots of little shops selling all sorts of items. Trendy bars and restaurants. Can be overcrowded in peak season in the ally ways but I highly recommend.

title: A lively, fun area!
content: The French Concession is a great way to spend a morning or afternoon. Even if you aren't shopping for knick-knacks, the little alleyways are interesting and there are plenty of things to keep your attention. Certainly worth a visit.

title: A nice historical place to visit
content: the small little paths are very enjoyable, so would recommend not sticking to the main road at all. Best to walk around during weekends, when there is much less traffic. Otherwise, could be a bit too hectic.

title: Truly Magnifique!
content: In the Old French Concession take a walk down Fenyang Road past Chaing Kai Shek's home to the Arts and Crafts Centre where you can see Chinese craftsmen at work....cutting paper patterns, embroidering, decorating dolls. Also visit scintillating Xintiandi. Feels like any European complex of restaurants with cuisine from all over the world. Lovely beer and wine bars...great place to spend an evening!

title: Architecture and History
content: I wasn't that impressed with the Old French Concession but there is history and the tree lined streets is probably unique in Shanghai, but with the traffic, and shops is was just another busy place for me.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Finding Paris in Shanghai
content: The French concession area was certainly one of the highlights of our visit to Shanghai. The tree lined streets with their French colonial architecture are a delight to stroll along. Some of the pedestrian areas which have been created with lots of outdoor cafes and restaurants are utterly charming, Xin Tian Di being the most interesting for us.

title: Home and the best of Shanghai
content: Walk around and explore for along as you like. There will always be another surprise around the corner.

title: A fascinating reminder of the past
content: The French concession is a large area n Shanghai which was given to the French during the 1930's, and run just l I've a slice of France, with it's own laws, police force and French-style architecture. Tree-lined streets are cool and beautiful, the buildings look like Paris, ands the characteristic Fuxing Park is a gem of lovely garden design. Enjoy the typical day in the. Park, watching the retired people doing tai chi, ballroom dancing, karaoke singing and fly ing kites. Retirement can be fun !

title: Great Dinner
content: A terrific area to visit for craft shopping and food. We enjoyed dinner at one of the restaurants where you could sit right on the street, great atmosphere.

title: A must for Westerners...lots of fun!
content: We loved going here because it really gives you an insight into how the east and west have influenced one another. There are great, affordable restaurants of every type and you can easy find get recommendations on other places to visit during your stay. Lots of great bars of all types.

title: Get lost around the area
content: The main Xintandi is cool, but starts feeling very toursity. Get lost around the alleys etc. and you'll find some real cute spots.

title: The western part of town, awesome fun
content: Full of great bars and restaurants and 2 excellent Jazz clubs, this is a great part of town for westerners. You'll find restaurants with French american and mexican menu's, great if you want an escape from the usual Chinese dinner.

title: Cute Area, Bars/Cafes
content: Walked around the area, but didn't spend the time to hangout at the cute Bars and Cafes. Looked like a nice area to spend some time hanging out with friends.

title: Charming
content: This section of the city is quite distinct and very charming. Lots of cafes and shops and lots to see by walking around.

title: Endless discovery material
content: Best is not too late in the morning or end afternoon, but also enough to see for long sunny sundays. The mix of very traditional chinese shops, restaurant and markets by now and then getting together or changed in to trendy and expat visited shops and places make every walk orignal. You have to know some of the best streets to walk on best itinerarys, like Yongkang Lu, Wulumuqi lu and Wuyuan lu. If you have a bike, it gets even better.

title: Great!
content: I guess we did not expect much, but we were captured by these small streets with shops and spend the whole afternoon strolling and in cafes.

title: French Quarter
content: Was expecting very old buildings but mostly have been rebuilt so a little like Las Vegas but good experience and must go

title: Great walking area, nice shops
content: If you have time, this is a beautiful area to take a walk and check out the boutique shops and small cafes.

title: Overated
content: Nice Leah streets and cafes but that's about it. Not really a tourist destination just something different. Lot of expats here

title: Really worth a tour
content: I I recommend a tour of the French concession and time to look at the small shops one aside the other where you can find nice handicraft, more stylish and at reasonable prices. Many options to have dinner in a picturesque environment. I booked a guide from Worldofnoodle, a Dutch lady who is living in Shanghai since a few years, who guided me through the hidden small streets and shared a lot of interesting information about Chinese way of living (seen with the eyes of an European lady)

title: chic
content: Nice neighbourhood, lively at night, pubs, restaurants, cafes, nice atmosphere. Good shopping, and all in all an elegant place to spend an afternoon and stay for dinner

title: Worth a Visit
content: We went to this place by mistake (not planed) then found it was a good mistake. Shanghai is a ultra modern city with serious and busy life but this area is very calm and quiet. We realy enjoyed the trip. Things are priced for tourists, be cautious.

title: pleasant walk
content: So good to see tree-lined streets & feel a different atmosphere in busy Shanghai. Some very friendly small businesses without high pricetags; and if you miss fetta cheese. olive oil, special pastries etc. just wander till you find the providore. Easy to wander off & get disoriented so keep the Metro corners in mind.

title: Too commercialized
content: If you are looking to feel the ambiance of the 1930sin this enclave, you are decades to late. What you will find are "chi -chi" shops selling expensive tourist items, coffe shops and overpriced restaurants. There is nothing very Chinese or French about this area at all. If you are looking forward to rubbing shoulders with other tourists, many being guided by a leader with a little yellow or red flag, by all means join the crowd!

title: My FAVORITE part of Shanghai!
content: Shanghai is a HUGE, ultra-modern city. So, when my guide took me to this part of the city, I couldn't believe what I was experiencing. It's quaint and even intimate in some ways. I spent several hours just walking around, enjoying the various shops and restaurants, and watching all of the other tourists like me who were in awe of what they were experiencing! I CANNOT recommend this area highly enough. In my opinion, it is a MUST SEE and experience attraction!

title: Stop for lunch
content: A quieter place to have a nice lunch or desert. Has a quaint charm about it and there is little traffic there.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Great area to stay
content: Excellent access to most of what Shanghai has to offer.  Walking distance to many places and shopping.

title: Fantastic western bars and restaurants
content: Great atmosphere and surroundings. It had a real western buzz. China does not have a bar culture, nor does it cater for non Chinese restaurants other than KFC or Macdonalds so the old French Concession is a little oasis which was in great demand after eating totally chinese food for three weeks.

title: Get lost
content: Walk aimlessly and you will see great things, don't be afraid to try street food even if you have no idea what it is or how to order.

title: Good food, bars, walking and hotels
content: this is the best place to stay when visiting the city. you will like the old world atmosphere, the trees and you will not be harrassed for massages and girls. this is the only place i stay in shanghai now, the tree lined streets are great for walking and the food options abound.

title: Enjoyed The Colonial Style of Old French Concession
content: The old french concession area has a colonial style to it with French trees lining the streets. Recommended to relax and take a walk to enjoy the atmosphere of this area.

title: Great evening
content: I spent a very enjoyable evening wandering around this area and visiting a couple of bars. It has a European feel to it and is definitely worth a wander. Bar prices are like UK pub prices but restaurant was cheap.

title: Looked this
content: This was almost like a European city inside Shanghai. I was told Jacky Chan bought it and renovated it. Doesn't feel like China. But don't forget you still can't drink the water or use ice.

title: Am I still in Shanghai - beautiful.
content: This area has made the China trip special on so many levels. The coolness of the streets, the Restaurants and shopping, the people, architecture. It's beautiful in a unique way.

title: Old made new
content: Get your walking shoes and go and discover this part of Shanghai, it is worthwhile.

title: Great old area
content: I like very much this area and I love to walk around here, the beautiful lined up old trees, the boutiques, the tea houses and restaurant . It is very pleasant a must do in Shanghai

title: So beautiful and so old
content: Just worth a walking around to get a feel for the real old china. Start at corner of Anfu Lu and Wooloomolooci Lu and just wander

title: dinner in the French Concession
content: During the day it is a nice place to stroll and then sit and watch the people go by. at night a thriving night spot with a myriad of restaurants.

title: Pick a few streets
content: Actually the French Concession is very big. One of my favorite streets is shaoxing lu, it is peaceful, has a small parc, some coffee shops and different gates you can enter and see how people live.

title: Okay, but nothing special
content: We ventured around the Old French Concession on a Saturday afternoon and were a little bored with it quickly. The homes are not nearly as neat as the architecture on the Bund and the Hutongs of Bejing are a whole lot cooler to see and walk. If you happen to be in the area, take a look, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see the area.

title: must do in shanghai
content: great place to have western style food,old french architecture,french cafes,restaurants,shopping malls,great bars

title: Walking tour a must
content: The French Concession is beautiful and soaked in history. There are many walking tours (I prefer the self- guided ones)available, and there's hardly a bad one. It's interesting enough that you could wander around with no guide at all, but that would be a shame because there are so many noteworthy points you would miss. Just a little prep will pay off handsomely. But in any case: do go, keep your eyes open and your camera at the ready.

title: Hidden Gems so take tips
content: We stayed on the border of the French Concession area and it took us two days to actually find some of the quaint side streets and bars. If planning to visit this area, take lots of your own maps and tips (local Shanghai map impossible to read) and write all the addresses of your chosen destinations down in Chinese as taxi drivers don't speak or read english.

title: Favorite place in Shanghai for a stroll
content: Having lived in Pudong, we liked to go over to Puxi now and again since that was the more traditional part of Shanghai. One of our favorite places to hang out on the weekend when we did wander that direction was the French Concession. This area contained the most unique architecture in the city. It was like wandering through a part of Europe in China. There were some nice smaller malls, some of which were quite elegant. There were also several very good restaurants (including Western spots that serve Mexican food, crepes, etc.). One of my favorite small bookstores in all of China was in the French Concession. There are plenty of things to do but, even apart from the shops and restaurants, a simple leisurely stroll along the tree-lined streets is a very relaxing way to spend a day.

title: Go soon.
content: It's a great place for a walk, to get a feel of the old Shanghai -- almost a miracle it's survived the onslaught of skyscrapers so long.

title: Gorgeous, human-scaled, walkable
content: Gorgeous plane trees line the graceful streets of the former French Concession, which retains many charming villas and housing with myriad styles, people cycle along the narrow streets, and the pace is less frenzied and more human-scale than many other parts of Shanghai. There are plenty of restaurants and shops to discover and the street scene is fascinating: food sellers spring up in street corners, hawkers sell handmade furniture, and people live their lives on the street, sitting out on the sidewalks, chatting with neighbors whilst fanning themselves or just watching the world go by. At night, bars come alive in different pockets. This is a mini city all on its own and you could spend days discovering what its windy streets have to offer.

title: Pretty empty on weekdays, weekends may be better
content: Some Halal food is pretty cool there. Nice pubs that offers canto pop and Mandarin pop.. Nice and Cheap drinks.. Good for relaxing and catching up with friends

title: Great part of Town
content: Lose the map and just wander around this area.  Great shops, cafes and architecture- very walkable, shady.

title: Stunning Area of Shanghai
content: This area is less Chinese than other parts of Shanghai but I loved the tree lined streets, stunning and unique fabrics and clothing (think Eileen Fisher Chinese style) and small cafes. Loved the Kommunist Cafe but it's western. After 13 days of Chinese food I was ready for a western-style vegetable egg white omelet and soy latte enjoyed outside.

user_loc: 阿根廷布宜诺斯艾利斯
title: Beautiful!
content: Loved this place! It´s great during the day and perfect during night! Drinking a beer in Paulander is a must! Enjoy!

title: Most beautiful part of time
content: Take your time and stroll through the area

title: Favorite Part of Shanghai
content: Tons of cool, hip cafes. Great place for lunch if you are on your way to Sun-Yat Sen's Former Residence, The Site of the First CPC National Congress, or just wandering! A little pricier than your average Shanghai street restaurants, but the food is definitely worth it. Most are actually French. The shops are miles better than the Yuyuan Bazaar (around Yuyuan Garden). It is almost like its own town and the sounds of the city are blocked out by the trees lining the streets on both sides. Clean too!

title: The prettiest part of Shanghai
content: Traffic can be an issue but the old area is nice, plenty of trees, lots of character and plenty of restaurants and bars.

title: Fascinating mix of old colonial and traditional chinese
content: Likes ...watching the chinese playing maJong,Xintiandi village,artificial but charming..throngs of yuppie chinese at play.

title: Cool place to shop
content: Not the same trinkets you see everywhere. Nice art galleries and shops with unique and unusal merchandise. Old buildings well preserved and very clean.

title: Architecture, big trees, great shops and food
content: The historic French Concession area of Shanghai boasts London Plane trees at 15' on center creating streets of total green shaded canopy. The variety of restaurants is impressive and many are french, hense a fav part of town for the french expats to live in. If you have ever wanted to live in france, but have a job in shanghai, give this a shot!

title: French Concession
content: Good walk and to explore a neighborhood in Shanghai. Getting a little too over the top with tourist stores. I like to walk around the neighboring streets to see what is going on with everyday life. Of course, like with any city, always be aware of your belongings and don't walk anywhere you feel you maybe getting yourself "lost". Since I'm single, I explore Shanghai by myself the majority of the time and I have never felt unsafe in Shanghai. However, I did get my IPod pickpocket.

title: Beautiful face of Shanghai
content: Shanghai has so many different faces, and this one should not escape your attention. It may be called French--it has a definitely European atmosphere, which nicely contrastst with the other faces of Shanghai.

title: Fun
content: Loved it, very quaint and plenty to look at. We went back twice and had lovely meals at a great price.....the bars are hilarious

title: Redone and saved history
content: This is a redone but saved historical area. There is a nice square with good shops and excellent restaurants. I particulary like the former Communist Party house Museum and the well known store Shanghai Tang. There is a nice bar to sit in and think about old Shanghai and a very special two storey restaurant that is just acroos the street from Shanghai Tang After visiting the square it is worth the walk around the area to really se the orginal French Concession

title: Leafy Sidestreets Make Wonderful Strolls
content: A different world from the Bund, Pudong and Nanking Road. A wonderful area to wander. Evenings are especially good for exploring. Lots of great restaurants too.

title: The heart of historic Shanghai
content: Very atmospheric, and a charming walk (with lots of trees to provide shade). A really interesting part of Shanghai, with some of the world's best Art Deco buildings. Do go on an escorted walk (Newman Tours) as you'll learn much more with their experienced, informed guides.

title: Nice area
content: This is a very nice area with different facades at day and night. At day it is nice to stroll, do some shopping in pleasantly calm and peacful surroundings. At night, many restaurants, bars and clubs open their gates for mainly tourists and foreigners.

title: Best to visit in cooler weather
content: We spent a couple of hours wandering around the French Concession starting from the Hilton Shanghai. Since it was June, we arrived back at the hotel exhausted and soaking in sweat. It was interesting to see what had happened to the old colonial-era houses and to see where Sun Yat-Sen and Chou Enlai had lived. It is worth a walk-through, but best in cooler weather!

title: Beautiful tree-scaped lanes for bike riding
content: One of the best ways to appreciate Shanghai is to hop on a bike and ride around - that way you can stop and start as and when you please, avoid the traffic and see things from a different angle.

title: A great way to see a portion of Shanghai
content: We were lucky that on that particular Sunday, an American gentleman was conducting a walikng tour of the French Concession - he does this once a month and our American hosts were keen that we join them also. It was a two hour walk through a quarter that seems to have withstood the ravages of the revolution. Beautiful homes and bungalows, all very well preserved, were pointed out as was the architecture which was very interesting.

title: This makes Shanghai
content: Your trip would not be complete without a trip to the French Concession. Don't be afraid to walk off the beaten track; you can wander for ages and you never know what you will come across. Absolutely great!

title: Must visit ! Old Shangahi
content: Love the feeling of walking down the street , makes you feel like old shanghai , even with all the towering buildings around .

title: Over rated
content: A place to buy poor quality at high prices unless you can bargain really well. But watch out for fakes.

title: Quaint European charm in Shanghai
content: What a pleasant surprise although a bit crowded in parts, this is such a well kept neighbourhood with lots of interesting restaurants and cafes. Would love to go back again, definitely worth spending a day walking around.

user_loc: 佛罗里达哈伦代尔海滩
title: Wonderful Cafes and a great palce to peole watch!
content: This area is full of old architecture, wonderful modern stores and great cafes. A great palce to peole watch. Also agood tourist site as there is the building where the Chinese Communist Party held its organizing conference which today houses a museum about the founding.

title: Another side of Shanghai
content: A lovely European, leafy area to relax and have lunch or dinner. We had lunch at South Beauty.

title: letdown
content: I could not find a bar here to save my life. Just upscale shops. Not even very picturesque; I kept looking for a place to photograph the architecture but no good angles. I was thirsty and disappointed

title: Meh
content: Maybe I missed the best parts but I didn't find this particularly worth the walk after a long day exploring shanghai. Seemed like it was just another built up area with western shopping malls and brand names (so I guess good if that's what you're looking for!). I think there is a nice museum or building that we couldn't find but not sure. We found a few nice french restaurants down an alley that might have been nice if you wanted that as opposed to chinese food. Not much real french architecture or feel though. Lots of cars and smog (like the rest of shanghai!).

title: Nice walk with interesting buildings
content: It's a very interesting stretch of road with many shops and boutique cafes. Do walk into the little side streets for more interesting shops and buildings.

title: A must-visit in Shanghai
content: The French concession is a fairly big area - the part I went to (Shao Xing Lu, recommended by DK guide) was very short. Another part called Julu Road is also nice.

title: Wonderful
content: Simply wonderful to walk around, see the little shops, always something new to check out.

title: Best area for restaurants and a flavour of the old times
content: Absolutely chock full of restaurants to suit all tastes, many with live music from jazz to rock to blues. Always busy so go early to ensure a table.

title: Classic area.
content: Nice buildings, plenty of trees, good eateries and pubs. Great for a day out, just stroll along and stop where you fancy.

title: Beautiful Architecture and some great pubs.
content: A really nice area to walk around during the day, and some great pubs for a drink in at night.

title: Not much to see
content: Maybe we just didn't find the right spots, but there wasn't much to see here. Yes, you can see some of the old, European-style buildings, but nothing else really remains such that it just felt like another shopping district.

title: Lovely Area
content: We were amazed at the Old French Concession and would recommended it to other travellers.

title: once upon a time
content: you have a few places to see but not much... worth the visit though

title: Good strolling area
content: Fun to walk around - blend old Shanghai with the new and is a nice contrast to the busy bits of town

title: A must visit!
content: It´s a lovely part of town. Very relaxing, beautiful and clean with interesting little shops, art and great restaurants

title: overated
content: its basically a food and drink elongated courtyard at best

title: Nice for a stroll
content: Nice tree-lined streets with some well preserved old villas and lots of local life.  Definitely worth exploring at your leisure.

title: Good for a walk
content: I walked around the area every weekend while I lived in Shanghai. I love the atmosphere and it's not obnoxiously touristy.

title: Nice place to walk and eat
content: Nice relaxing place to walk and eat and enjoy.

title: It is so beautiful
content: I have been living in Shanghai for the last 15 years and I just can't stop walking the streets in the former French Concession. Tree lined streets provide ample shade in summertime and the streets are lined by beautiful old mansions. They used to be surrounded by high walls, but many walls have been demolished and replaced by gates so one can see the beautiful (sometimes delapidated) gardens and mansions again. Fuxing Road is one of my favorite streets to walk. And don't forget to stop by Fuxing Park on weekends in particular.

title: French cafes in a Chinese setting
content: If you want a break from Chinese food head to the French Concession for a bit if cafe life

title: time to go shopping
content: I hate shopping but this was fun just walking around and trying to make a deal

title: An "old" district with Chic modern shops & dining- definitey worth a 2nd visit............
content: We came in the night & the place was just so beautifully lit up. Its very different from the usual modern shppping malls or district.

title: A touch of Europe in China
content: Not cheap but pleasant to sit outside. Good selection of places to eat and drink.

title: little france
content: nice to stroll around the narrow streets shops and sit in a good restaurant, bar or just for coffee we were there at day time but ive heard its lovely at night as well

title: Rent a bike
content: Try to rent a bike, or even buy one at Carrefour for less than 200 rmb, and take it for a spin around the leafy streets. Always a bunch of cafes to grab a coffee or lunch.

title: Europe in China
content: A part of Shanghai with a more European feel - restaurants, coffee shops etc plus the history attached.

title: Lots to see!
content: Small alleys of many shops and restaurants. Variety of ethnic foods to be had here. I would go back again because I am sure I missed a lot!

title: Enjoyable
content: Worth a stroll thru in just about any weather, decent ambience, good eateries and lots of history.

title: Nice feel
content: A part of shanghai with a bit of a western feel, when you stay in China for a long time, like I did, you're going to long for western food, this is the place to go. You can also find winebars and nice backyard pubs.

title: A must see and live in Shanghai for expats
content: There is not much more to say than this is the expat place to see and live. It is so full of little shops, cafes, restaurants and parks that it is a bit difficult to define by a few places. Cozy in winter , cool in summer; go have a look and stroll throughout the maze of streets.

title: Europe in China
content: I spent one evening here and it was totally unexpected. Walking along here and you could easily mistake that you were in europe. Really great to see all the old buildings havent been torn down and it is a very pleasant area. Lots of nice restaurants and bars and highly recommend going for dinner or a drink in this area.

title: Pleasant and Interesting
content: We toured the old french concession and found it very pleasant, not as crowed as other parts of Shanghai. The shopping was upscaled, but not over the top.

title: Things are changing, but worth a stroll
content: The area is developing rapidly, but even the new malls have shops of interest that are not found everywhere. Still, there are small, unique boutiques that give a real taste of the interest in indy fashion. Wahder around the leafy side-streets and look down teh alleys for views of old Shanghai.

title: better then shopping in no wheres land
content: architecture, good fibe, old Shanghai, no regrets. since this city is not much about old China, the french Concession is a real treat. Not that all buildings are Shanghai 1920, but still, there is something to it. and whilest the T 8 Restaurant is a good start, just try the streets behind and you might never want to leave!

title: Not much to see, but you have to go!
content: I have to admit that my expectations were higher why I probably feel a bit disappointed. I had expected more in regards to architecture and historical things, but as Shanghai less than 200 years old there's really isn't much too see. Most of the old historical buildings are being restored or seem to have been 'face-lifted' without paying too much attention to the original look. A russian orthodox church, a few famous residences and the occasional well-preserved house is to be found.

title: Do not miss if in Shangai
content: Great shopping, eating, architecture and walking highly recommend it.

title: Excellent area
content: Great area to explore. Nice bars and restaurants. Easy to get there.

title: A fun and interesting day out!
content: After reading the glowing reviews about the French Concession, we decided to make a day of it and head over for ourselves and check it out. Easily accessible and directly opposite Dapuqiao subway station, we visited the Tianzifang area as recommended by LP and it was awesome fun.

title: Magnolia B&B
content: I stayed here for a week. The location is excellent especially for exploring the former French Concession. The owners do NOT live on the premises and do not visit often, so there is little local advice. They do provide a local map to find restaurants, pharmacies, etc.

title: Just like being in France
content: What a great place to go for lunch! We took a taxi there from our hotel (the Concierge wrote the name in Chinese for the taxi driver). It was nice to experience the ambience of Paris, with lots of cafes and restaurants to select from for lunch or afternoon tea. Highly recommended.

title: Must go
content:
This is the 'cute European city' version of Shanghai. 

Less high-density-50-story-buildings-packed-with-white-collar-workers, more shorter-'original'-older-Shanghai-ese-charm.

More Munster, Less Frankfurt.

title: Love It
content: Great place to shop and get a good thin crust pizza and wine and people watch ...

title: Seemed like the coolest neighborhood in city
content: We walked around for couple hours.  Nice tree lined streets, good restaurants and shopping.   FAR better than many of the "nicer" modern sections of Shanghai which are sterile and largely malls with no character.

title: Spend a while getting lost
content: Interesting narrow alleys full of wonderful surprises - take time to enjoy a drink in a comfy chair and take in the atmosphere.

title: Very charming
content: A day of leisure strolling up the tree lined avenues brings a bit of quietness to the busy Bund area. Quaint restuarants and shops take you back in time.

title: Worth the walk
content: Although it is sometimes hard to see the mansions, now hidden behind high fences and greenery for privacy, it is well worth taking the time to explore this little piece of history is a rapidly modernising environment.

title: Excellent place to chill out
content: Must go there, regretefully I didnt have enough time to spend there as I was on a business trip. Lots of cafes, shops and clubs, everyone will find something to appeal to him there. Dont miss it

title: A little disappointing
content: We had trouble finding the French Concession. I think because it didn't particularly stand out and it didn't seem very French. There were a few streets with avenues of trees and old buildings but they had been restored in such a way that they looked almost new. There were also a few coca cola signs on shops that spoiled the illusion.

title: Loved loved loved this place
content: I strongly recommend a day traveling around this area get a ricksaw and take in the sights wonderful french food crepes art antiques etc loved it.

title: Paris in Shanghai
content: Think tree lined avenues, french bakeries and a smattering of cool boutiques - you could be in Paris!

title: A Shanghai highlight
content: An unexpected bonus to a great trip. We spent hours just wandering the narrow shop lined paths. No cars make this a great hand out, especially if you stop at one of the tiny bars with the stools out front -- great people watching.

title: Highly recommended
content: Wonderful area which could be anywhere in Paris, wide streets, shade from old trees, street cafes and quaint shops. Perfect for strolling around. Many different restaurants.

title: Safe place for walking around
content: Great are to be popping into small boutiques, restaurants, knicknack shops & enjoy a relaxed photoshooting day.

title: BEST place to start with Shanghai history
content: This was the beginning of the social revolution and seems to be the start of the materialistic revolution. If you want to see the best of Shanghai, just talk a walk around these streets

title: A great evening people watching
content: Definitely worth visiting for all manner of cafes, restaurants and boutique stores offering unusual gift ideas.

title: Real China for the inner city folks...
content: Walk this area... try the foods... take photos and see how the locals live.

title: Beautiful restoration
content: Nothing to dislike. It has really preserved a piece of history from pre-War of Japanese Agression. Shops and eateries are delightful.

title: Cozy ,expensive but charming
content: FC is place to enjoy with friends with a lot variety of clubs,restaurants,cafe....price is expensive but visit there never make you dissapointed,old school Shanghai rich of fashion and history!

title: Exploring Shanghai
content: Include a walking tour when visiting Shanghai - best way to explore is on foot!

title: the area of shanghai
content: this is where all the life is happening, foreigners run different places there, many bars, restaurants or shops, lots of contrast between the modern china and the old one, still some old areas with the normal shanghai street life...

title: nice feel
content: we did a cycling tour around parts of it - great experience

title: interesting  not quite what i had expected but nice to  be able to get the feel of what the place was like
content: Could be more well preserved and more imformation about it in hotel lobbies.

title: Fun to visit, a bit touristy though
content: Fun little shops and bars, nice in the early evening for apero

title: Fun place to visit
content: We met up with a local European who knew his way around and we had a great time finding quaint bars to explore. The back streets were an experience, it was vibrant and fun.

title: A special place to visit
content: Love the structure of the buildings there, we took lots of photos.

title: OK neighborhood, bit touristy
content: Very touristy.  Average food, but a good place to go if you want some western food options.

title: A Peaceful Promenade
content: Walk this neighborhood to remove yourself from the hustle, bustle city life of Shanghai. This neighborhood has the atypical serene and peaceful characteristic of everyday China. It is full of stylish shops such as art galleries and boutiques where commercial space is allowed. Don't expect to find any bargains as things are expensive here catering to primarily upper class and ex-pats.

user_loc: 哥伦比亚特区华盛顿特区
title: Very fun area to walk around and shop
content: Walking through the French Concession gives you a completely new view of Shanghai and shouldn't be missed. The shopping and cafes were all excellent, and my brother and I really enjoyed wandering around.

title: Stay in this area!
content: Beautiful tree lined streets, many shops and restaurants. Overall we liked this area better than the Bund area.

title: A slighly slower pace of life
content: It's still pleasant to walk around this area, especially Fuxing Park on a weekend, Ruijin Park and Hotel. Lots of shops and boutiques but a more pleasant and less hectic atmosphere compared to the many modern shopping malls. Going west towards Jing'an the area becomes distinctly more ex-pat.

title: A bit disappointing
content: A huge area, really, with glimpses here and there of the old style buildings, surrounded by lots of less attractive ones. The extensive plantings of plane trees are lovely, watching kite flyers and local waltzers in the park fun, and maybe the best part is the smaller, sort of winding roads with less traffic. Makes walking around enjoyable.

title: A walk back in time yet a glimpse into young Shanghai
content: Well-preserved buildings from the period, the French Concession is lined with great trees, making it a favoured walking round during the warmer, sunnier months. Stroll around and marvel at the number of buildings that are preserved, restored and renovated, from late 19th Century buildings to the heyday of the art deco movement, make sure you have a camera with you.

title: Beautiful, atmospheric Old Shaghai
content: Take a walking tour ! it's full of charm and unexpected surprises in terms of shops, architecture and eateries!

title: Mix of Shopping, New and Old
content: It's a good resting place, just relax here and spend a pretty penny. It's where all the foreigners go so expect to have this remind you of Europe or your hometown. This isn't China but it's a nice escape.

title: Another Face Of Shanghai
content: My husband and I set out for a wander around the area on the weekend. We had not really researched or planned the day but found a wealth of interesting niches for us to explore. We found a wonderful French bakery and a wonderful lunch at a little French cafe. The neighborhood has great examples of different architecture and I could have spent hours in Fuxing Park watching locals have fun. It was easy to get there via the subway. It was hard to find a decent restroom though. I suspect that there was a whole lot more to see had we planned more and had the confidence to go into more places. I'll be back in 10 weeks and I think I'll book a tour with someone like 'Noodle Tours' to really get the most out of this intriguing neighborhood.

title: Worth the walk
content: Even though it was raining, the walk was interesting.  We had a really interesting and informative guide.

title: Charming Quarter!
content: The Old French Concession is no longer French but rather filled with trendy boutiques and nice craftsmanship products of any kind. The narrow streets makes you feel like you entered a maze and you'll get surprised by loosing yourself into it!

title: Fascinating
content: The old colonial houses and relatively quiet wide treelines streets hold many suprises like the tea house and restaurant in the Old English Embassy, a bit run down, but charming and historically interesting. There are many boutiques, individual food shops, cheap delicious restaurants, and hair and massage places. We recommend restaurants Guyi (Hanan traditional cooking)(spicy lots of chilli)on Fumin Road £35 for 3 of us with drinks, Lost Heaven also in FConcession -delicious food lots of French eat here, The subconcious Spa on Fumin Road where massage for 1 hour is £25, clean, friendly, safe and hairdressers Twelve where I had a blow dry on long hair for £8.(No english spoken but I described what I wanted with gestures)

title: Interesting
content: This area is very interesting and well worth a visit, especially withy a guide.

user_loc: 加利福尼亚帕洛斯弗迪斯庄园
title: Touristy but nice for a stroll and people watching
content: Aside from the title of my review which says most of what needs to be said - a thank you to the developers for preserving these historical, human scale buildings in this dense high-rise city. It is a bit of an oasis from the intensity of Shanghai and worth a side trip if you have the time and will be in the area or nearby. Of course everything is pretty much just a cheap taxi ride away in central Shanghai.

title: Tourist Trap and Expensive Restaurants
content: Recycled buildings jazzed up as upmarket coffee shops and restaurant. Only for the new Chinese Millionaires and their girlfriends. Even the tourist baulked at the price of a coffee $8AUD

title: Shopping area
content: Although the buildings are good to view, I would say you could drive through it and get the vibe without getting out to wander. However if you are into high end fashion or shopping for deluxe wares, it is worth a visit.

title: Great for a stroll
content: Fuxing road in particular is beautiful. Be sure to stop at Boxing Cat Brewery (either location) for a good microbrew outside.

title: A little bit overrated
content: French Concession, there is nothing french in it except the tourists! I dont like it much because of the mess and the expat fame there!

title: plenty to see and spend money on
content: The old buildings were marvellous and winding up and down the lanes was a continual surprise of young and innovative chinese entrepreneurship. Some of the photography is world class and there are plenty of nick nack and food shops to visit. Pottery and art works are everywhere and there are even Tibetan art and craft shops. It is easy to spend most of the day here, a lovely Sunday afternoon entertainment.

title: really good place to hang out
content:
buildings, the road, situation just perfect!!
Restaurants are perfect too!!

title: Interesting architecture.
content: Went on a Sunday morning firstly to Fuxing Park and watched all the older people dancing and exercising, playing cards, having their blood pressure checked! Terrific experience and great for people watching. Everyone was very friendly and relaxed. Then wandered for a number of hours through the French concession. Wonderful architecture and very peaceful, defintely feel like it's going back a few decades. A must see.

title: Fantastic area for wandering around
content: This area is made up of low rise (<5 storey) buildings

title: Beautiful neighborhood
content: The tree-lined streets are picturesque. Definitely worth seeing, as it has a different feel than the rest of Shanghai. Buy a street walking tour map to find interesting facts about the neighborhood.

title: Cosy
content: Great place. Will go back again if we had the time. Great to see the original Shanghai.

title: Old town
content: Was surprised to find some old building still existed today.  The areas with tree lined street are beautiful!

title: Spend the afternoon here
content: The Old French Concession used to be a residential area. It is built like small European towns and is now filled with little curio shops and places to eat. Beware of buying a Coke off the stand my friend paid RMB30 for a can at one of the restaurants with and outdoor stand.

title: A nice respite
content: A great place to wander and browse the cute shops. The trees and colonial buildings provide a nice respite to all the high rise hustle and bustle of the rest of the city.

title: Step back into time
content: Walking around the French Concession you are transported back to an earlier time. The architecture is interesting and you immediately feel like you are back in the early 20th Century.

title: China's George Washinton area
content: The area is definitely showing it's Europe influence. The area we visited was the home Zhou Enlai. China giving its story of how it started. Ok, not the best visit.

title: I LIVE HERE!!! IT'S AWESOME!!!
content: this is pretty much dead center downtown for shanghai, great places for both big brand name shopping and miniature cute stores too! and not to mention lots of food!

title: This is what makes Shanghai, Shanghai
content: Arguably Shanghai doesn't have its share of overt cultural landmarks like Beijing but this place gives you the sense of how the present day Shanghai became a real 'fusion' with European cities. The architecture, nuances and tree-lined avenues remind of a not so long ago bygone age where European settlers and prospectors left their mark. Shanghai has re-claimed its territory but there remains the remnants of the rise of the 'treaty port' and the amazing influences it weaved into the fabric of what they used to call the 'Paris of the East'

title: A Nice Walk in a Big City but all is overpriced
content: You want to get out, feel comfortable in the many Western style pubs and restaurants... like to people watch? Shop in local and international stores? Take a stroll in the French Concession. We shopped a bit...were astounded that one department store entitled, Number One Dept Store, had an entire floor with shoes! Another entire floor with women's coats and jackets, etc. There's abundance in Shanghai.

title: nice area for a walk
content: French concession is a great area for a walking tour,afternoon coffee,boutique shopping,art and history exploring etc.It's a nicest area to live in Shanghai.

title: Lovely area for a day walk
content: This area is so different from other parts of Shanghai. So peaceful and full of little shops selling cheap overstock designer items for set price. It is definitely worth a visit.

title: Nice neighborhood
content: Lot of fancy restaurants and many shops. Nice place to wander round for an hour.

title: looking for somewhere to wander?
content: This is the best area for wandering around - explore a few alleys, stop at a cafe or grab some street food. Nice mix of colonial architecture and local culture.

title: A must visit
content: The French Concession is a very nice place with very nice architecture and beautiful tree lined streets with boutiques, restaurants and cafes.

title: Walking through the really unrestored section with guide from 'World of Noodles' should not be missed!
content: A three hour or so walking tour guided by a knowledgeable expat who lives in Shanghai is the only way to see and really appreciate how people live now, and lived years ago, in this special section of Shanghai. We recommend the "World of Noodles" tour highly and plan to arrange to use them again on our next visit.

title: Favourite part of Shanghai
content: Hengshan Road area great for bars and clubs. We love Sachas for a quiet drink and Zappatas party vibe! The Parisian feel of the streets and nice green parks make this area an oasis amongst the hustle and bustle of Shanghai.

title: Traditional Shanghai
content: Lovely old buildings, many restored. New life from boutiques, art shops, guest houses, cafes. Reliving the romance of a bygone era. Sadly streets are filthy as you pick your way through spit and dog poo.

title: Nice area to walk around in - or live in!
content: We lived in the French Concession between 2005-2009 and it developed during those years to become a buzy area with excellent small boutiqes and many nice restaurants.

title: The best part of the city
content: The French Concession is the place to live and visit for Shanghai expats--lots of greenery, cool shops, great restaurants, and vintage houses.

title: Laneways and old architecture
content: Beautiful old colonial buildings and interesting laneways.

title: Nice way to spend an afternoon
content: Hard to find but worth a visit. nice little shops but not really cheap by China standards.

title: We loved it and we'll be back.
content: We loved Shanghai, but especially loved the old french area. There were lovely shops, restaurants and the whole area was very relaxing. We made our way there by the subway and had one adventure after another.

title: Lovely trendy place to hang out
content: The French Concession was a former suburb of Shanghai, and it has beautiful tree lined streets with boutiques, restaurants and cafes. It's a great place to hang out and have a glass of wine and people watch. Pricier than a lot of other areas, but great for a leisurely stroll.

title: Best Thai food ever !
content: Simply Thai in Dong Ping Lu is simply the best Thai food ever! Every dish is authentic, balanced well, full of flavour and hearty. Service is also excellent.

title: nice parks, streets and eats
content: Take the subway here and stroll a few blocks to the lovely Fuxian gardens, where you can watch people practicing their dancing and tai chi. Lovely plantings. A few blocks away was a street where they had many different restaurants, including a British fish n chips place that served some of the best delicately-fried fish I have ever had. A good break to have something different to eat. Good beer selection, too. The bars across the street looked like they had live music, and there was a variety of shops.

title: Nice stroll in morning
content: Walked for about 2 hours and went by xintiandi to people's square. Serene and tree lined before the hustle and bustle of the rush hour.

title: Great section
content: Great little different area around Shanghai.  Trees line the streets and several shops.  Definitely recommend for something different in China that then normal building.  Some great restaurants for Westeners as well with a large ex-pat community around.

title: FFC
content: I stayed in an Airbnb near Tianzifang, and I'm so glad i stayed in this area rather than the Bund. So much nicer, greener, more relaxed. Enjoyed returning to the FFC at the end of the day after touring the more crazy areas.

title: Lots of places for foodies
content: As well as beautiful shops selling exclusive clothing and leathergoods there are a number a restaurants selling expensive food. The day we were there Wolfgang Pucks restaurant had a $300 degustation advertised on a sandwich board outside. Built around a square the laneways leading off have a lot of cafes and bars that you can eat at outside so you can watch the world going past. Definitely a tourist trap but still worth visiting.

title: Amazing Alleyways of wonderment!
content: Feels like you are not in Shanghai when you walk around the French area. Tea is very cheap and so are scarfs and other things you need to pick up. If you feel you are lost at some point just look out for the alleyways. Explorers Galore here!

title: The old part of town from the periode of French concession 1850 to 2nd World War
content: This is an old, charming part of Shanghai with small boutiques, barber shops, massage parlors, not to forget small restaurants, bars and appartments. A must to see in Shanghai.

title: A must see in Shanghai
content: A couple of hours walking through the French Concession, some People watching, lots of pictures, and great moments. Kind of time travel to past era of Shanghai.

title: Quiet in the noise
content: I like to visit the old Shanghai more the modern parts, especially to those old house that famous celebrities in the past. Due to complex history with Shanghai, it offers more opportunities than other cities in China. I like to spend a day to stroll in some quiet lanes and enjoy the local life here in Puxi to have my own time.

title: Colonial city like old french lanes very place to hangout when you are shanghai , can have coffee at french look like
content: Good Colonial city like old french lanes very place to hangout when you are shanghai , can have coffee at french look like

title: Charming place.....
content: This part of Shanghai is a must on anyone's list of to do's when visiting. The shops and bars have a great charm and give a nice snapshot into the past. Be warned through this area can be expensive.

title: Nice
content: The street itself is very clean and calm. However only few buildings are different in style.

title: Beautiful Buildings
content: This area was beautiful and historic. We did visit the birthplace of the Communist party. I thought the restaurants were very Westernized. This whole are seemed more like Europe than China.This is part of the history of the city. Nice place for a very short visit.

title: A quick detour
content: I visited the french concession without any expectation, but I was pleasantly surprised.

title: SiNan Road
content: Walking on HuaiHai Rd, you could visit all the old but stylish things at once. I love the atmosphere of Former French Concession very much. It is pity I bumped into rain so did not have as much fun as i expected. I will be back.

title: This is the old colonial China I always wanted to see
content: This is place to walk and watch and taste. Many small shops / restaurants and romantic old movies look-a-like places. Enjoy!

title: People Watching & taking in the Beauty Around
content: Loved this area. It was nice to relax with a coffee at 1 of the lovely patisseries & take in the masses of people who come to this area. If someone blindfolded you & plopped you down here you would swear you're in France. It gets very busy as the day progresses but friends tell me morning time is less hectic less tour groups. A bit more expensive but nice to take time out

title: romantic place
content: we got a tour to there . we went at night. that was beautiful and romantic place . i like there and recommend  to see .

title: Great for city walks
content: Walks in the area are much fun. It doesn't feel like a Chinese city in some areas, especially xin tian di. Bring along a map (or use baidu maps if you read Chinese) or just walk around and discover new things!

title: A Place to watch the world go by
content: Had a day free to roam the city and found myself here. Interesting architecture; old 2-storey buildings amidst the highrise, modern backdrop. Spent the afternoon in one of the many cafes sipping coffee and just watching the people go by.

title: Good Place - I feel I am in Istanbul - Nişantaşı
content: I do not believe Shangai in China. If you are in Shangai, you should never miss this place. It will worth it.

title: A Different Side of Shanghai
content: This part of Shanghai offers visitors a different side and perspective of its cultural and architectural history. The old side of Shanghai.

title: Nice building
content: French concession is within Xintiandi. We saw some old nice building. But most already been refurbish and er found many modern shopping centres along the trail. We took the waking trial recommended and it was a long walk. We were totally down after the walk. Pls wear comfortable shoe if u intend to do the walking trail.

title: Don't miss the French Concession
content: Especially if you are hungry for some non-chinese food after a few weeks.  Lots of nice shops and restaurants.

title: History immobile
content: Walking through the, French Concession, mainly the district of Xuhui and surrounding it, one feels like history stood still. The old elm trees, or platane in French, line most of the streets, as is typical in a lot of French cities. And two things are evident, Street cleaners now have to sweep up leaves as well as street debris; And you can hear birds chirping, probably the only place in the city with birds!

title: True China
content: Unfortunately there is not much left of the old China in Shanghai. But the French concession is very well worth a half day stroll among the old buildings and all the new shops. You can also see the old Chinese shops and small restaurants with no English menus. Just walk around with no plan.

user_loc: 文莱达鲁萨兰斯里巴加湾
title: Nice evening spot
content: A nice place to go at night. Lots of westernize drinking areas, bars and restaurants. It's a nice place to hang around at night

title: Nice walk and European flair
content: Nice place to go for a walk and visit historic homes. Plenty of shops and restaurants in the area. Large Westerner population.

title: A walk to the past of Chinese history during French occupation
content: A walk through the French con session is a walk towards China's past during French occupation of a sector of Shanghai. You walk through narrow alleyways, old homes, many renovated to house restaurants, bars, and shops. One sees how people lived in the past.

title: french in shanghai
content: very interesting  walking trip in old french concession and  old plane trees, and is highly condensed with exquisite, tiny restaurants.

title: Wonderful walking tour
content: Check out Frommer's website for Shanghai and get the walking tour they suggest. Lots of interesting shops with local artwork and calligraphy. There's a section with pedestrian walkways with lots of shops and restaurants that you can take a break, rest your feet and get some delicious food. Well worth a half day during your stay in Shanghai.

title: A piece of old Shanghai
content: Shanghai is not only about skyscrapers and fancy fashion houses in Huaihai. In Old French Concession you can find beautiful spots, nice old houses and tree-lined streets, small cafes and bars, and tiny old style shops. It’s definitely worth of exploring by walk.

title: Very nice place
content: This place is very nice, although in my opinion it resembles some quarters of London, more than that of Paris. Was inhabited by the French and in the 1920 ies, by Russians, who escaped after the revolution. A lot of cafes, quite moderate in price and shops, which are very expensive, a lot of people all the time. Very nice Pizza Express restaurant with fast service and good food.

title: Is definitely a misture of richness and poor. I liked
content: Is a place where you see people from all over the world but also rich and poor chines people. You got luxurious restaurants and very simple street little chines restaurants that i love it you can eat for like 15RMB like 3 dollars, nice fresh noodle. The only thing is very expensive every where around here is tge coffee no cheap option. The roads are all full of three i like this place and probably will stay here again.

title: Huge Area
content: This is a huge area to review and takes in a major part of old Shanghai. I have visited here 8 years ago and again in 2015. I was amazed to see how the area has transformed itself into a world class tourist, residential and heritage area. Many new shops and restaurants and spectacular sites. Some must see sites are the Fuxing Park area, St Nicolas Church, the landmark Art Deco Cathay Cinema,and the 1926 Okura Garden Hotel which contains spectacular Art Deco interiors including a restaurant, Ball room and an amazing entrance lobby with Grecian nude figures in base relief. Spared in the cultural revolution from any harm because it was Chairman Mao's favourite hotel. Also must sees are the Jinjiang hotel and surrounding buildings which are a major concentration of important Art Deco and Art Moderne Buildings.

title: Most interesting part of Shanghai
content: If you want to experience the old Shanghai with a mix of Europeen and Chineese this is where you should go. Nice cafe's and great shopping (in the streets and in numoures shoppingmalls).

title: A quick visit, but an worthwhile one
content: I had an afternoon to spare in Shanghai before I returned to the UK, and grabbed a taxi to take me to the French Concession. I enjoyed my walk short round the tree lined streets, and saw some interesting fusion between French and Chinese architecture and culture. I also saw possible the smallest tailors shop in the world, owned by a dapper old gent who was all smiles and professionalism. It was worth the effort just to see him! I wish I had been able to stay longer, and if I return to Shanghai then I will build in a proper visit to this historic part of old Shanghai.

title: Lovely part of the city
content: This part of Shanghai is lovely, with tree-lined streets and a maze of shops and cafes. This is the perfect place in Shanghai to stroll through the city and experience the local lifestyle in this relaxed European neighborhood. There are a variety of nice restaurants with great food, and some fun and unique shops to explore.

title: Gorgeous old style architecture
content:
Quaint and steeped in European history and the French participation in trading in Shanghai.
Walking this zone is recommended.

title: French Concession--Shanghai
content: To absorb it's contrasting history when visiting the captivating city of Shanghai, it's equally important to explore the French Concession in 'old Shanghai' as it is to see the more recommended & publicized attractions dotted throughout the newer business & Hotel sector.

title: A night in the French Concession
content: I have lived in this area as an ex-pat for almost a year now and I am so happy this is where we chose to live. It has everything you could ever want from modern fashionable Restaurants and bars, to quaint back street Chinese places where you can eat and drink with the locals.

title: Must see area...only $4 USD taxi ride from across town
content: The OFC is a dead knock off of European walkplatz's. Tons of restaurants, coffee shop galore and shopping till your wallet explodes. OFC has tree lined streets, umbrella and shaded seating areas for coffee shops & restaurants, and an ultra cool vibe in the heart of Shanghai. When the temp rises, duck into an air conditioned mall and enjoy a cool beverage while strolling the pristine floors. OFC is definitely a Western designed part of town, and enjoyed by all.

title: Piece of Europe in Shanghai
content: Lovely place. Roads with many trees, lovely mixture between new and old architecture. Big and sophisticated Shoping center. Lovely restaurants and cafes. Also lovely food to eat at street. Beautiful and trendy people. Lots of foreign as well. Definitely a lovely place to meet and to stay.

title: Great Architecture
content: The French Concession part of Shanghai has a great atmosphere and great architecture. It is very different from most of the rest of the city. A lot of the buildings are very well preserved and are now eating places. A real mix of old and new. The concession was established in 1849 and ran until 1943.

title: Sprawling, but only a couple of streets of interest
content: We got off the line 1 metro station at Shaanxi Road and that's where the French confession starts. then walked to Fuxing Park before continuing along Fuxing road to the European cafe streets at the junction of Madang Road. Here you could be on a street in Paris. Lots of Cafes but beware as its expensive. It was also busy when we went as Shanghai Fashion week was centred nearby. Overall an interesting walk but watching the locals at Fuxing park was the highlight for me not the cafes or architecture

title: New and Old
content: An old french concession turned to be a new and beautiful area filled with branded items malls and shops. Western restaurants and coffee shops. Still you can notice the olden arch design house attached to the new era.

title: French style
content: We have just had a relaxing walk around the French Concession. Although it would have been good to have a guide it was lovely just walking and getting the vibe. We walked between metro stops South Shaanxi and Huangpu on Line I via the Fuxing Park. There are lots of interesting snacks to try, designer boutiques and the park was full of dancing classes, choir and Jazz practice. An inexpensive and charming place to visit.

title: Stay for the photos
content: This place is a beautiful maze of shop and cafe. Once cafe I like is simply which is a modern Chinese cafe. I suggest you to stay for the photos and enjoy your shopping at tian zi fang

title: Yet another pricey place to shop
content: This area of Shanghai has some historical value to it, however, it is currently filled with name brand stores with high end goods. It's a pretty enough area to hang out and walk around. The bathrooms were decent as far as Chinese bathrooms go. I was drawn to one store and quickly ran for the hills when I saw a hoodie was going to cost me around $500 (American!).

title: A ral taste of Shanghai
content: We didn't have as much time as we would have like. We went to a garden, very old, very beautiful , one of several that were on our tour. Enjoyed the atmosphere, and different kind of shopping.

title: Always new
content: There is a lot of sophisticated Shanghai in this area, and always something new to discover. The area is very large, and there is often one more little street that you may not have seen before. Restaurants, bars, coffee shops, retail, photo opportunities, hipsters, chic businesswomen, cute school kids, obnoxious old ladies and real Shanghainese. Delightful.

title: Nice view and shopping, eating area
content: I recommend this for people who really love shopping and eating good food. For those who love spending money on good things. It is also wonderful for sight seeing.

title: Old French Concession Area - Nice Architecture!
content: The Old French Concession area of Shanghai is a very pretty neighborhood with attractive older architecture which contains small apartment buildings, restaurants and stores. It is a pleasant place to walk and explore the low rise stone and brick façade buildings on tree lined streets.

title: Great place to wander, well restored
content: We spent a day wandering around, from busy restored shopping areas to the old writers room/cafe, to the small parks and lovely tree lined avenues. A great step back in time.

title: The most irresistible view in Autumn
content: Walking along the street under the trees which has been planted over 50 years. Especially when the leaves fell down on the street. It turned into golden street all of sudden under the sunshine.There are four streets recommended as below:

title: Feels as if you have stepped out of Shanghai...great restaurants & cafe's
content: The Old French Concession is a great place to visit, especially if you have a few days in Shanghai. I travel there often and love the city but sometimes, it can get overwhelming and you want a slice of something different and the French influences, cafe's shops and restaurants in this area really do that. It is a large area and there is so much to do!

title: Unique Area to Visit
content: The area certainly provided lots of walking for us. Its very different than the rest of the city.Once designated as the french living section of the city it now has many updated tudor buildings along the tree lined streets with many shops, cafes and restaurants.

title: Time for a Coffee
