content: Just sit back and relax and watch the world pass. New and Old. The culture, the boutiquetie shops, cafes, homes and very special. Its like a theatre, a village in a huge city. a must see for half or full day.

title: Great place for a stroll
content: We spent an afternoon in the French Concession area and it was one of our favourites of the 5 days we spent there. The area is quite big. There are the very commercial busy parts along Huaihai Middle Road and then there are the quiet neighbourhoods. Our favourite is a little triangular area in between Changle Road, Donghu Road, and Shaanxi S. Road. There are a bunch of little boutique shops, restaurants and cafes. I would recommend skipping the stores at the big malls and do your shopping here instead. Afterwards, find a nice patio and grab a bit or a drink. We did not have dinner here, but a couple places we saw had very upscale looking dining rooms that we would definitely be checking out when we come back to Shanghai again.

title: A peaceful stroll
content: You can find quite easily on the internet the recommended path to stroll through the neighborhood .We did about half of the path (mainly down Sinan road).Its a special blend of leafy tree sidewalks along French village type architecture , animated with the Chinese population on bikes and electric motorcycles ali of this peppered with boutique shops .The road ends at the Taikang maze of alleys which is another attraction to integrate in your stroll.

title: Nice place
content: If you're into western restaurants and nice shops it's a cool place to go to. I thought "Tian Zi Fang" is better

title: Sneak inside the Old French Concession block for a diverse art, people, food experience
content: It's like a Persian market on a Chinese tight village labirinth in French walk-thru style, where afluent, poor and regular Chinese meet visiting expatriates (mostly Europeans) with their businesses in almost every trade and craft category, from food, to fake fashion stuff, to carved wood, to jelwery, bars, painting galleries, photographs and so on. Capice?Split a full day to experience it and put a nice lunch in between halves. Walk slowly, take pictures, buy that gadget after a nice bargain of at least 30% less, try the ice cream. Make it in a work day if possible, unless you are OK with crowds typically flowing in week ends. Enjoy.

title: Nice area with lots of places to eat
content: Great area for restaurants and cafes in a beautiful setting. You wouldn't know this was Shanghai because of the European style architecture in this area.

title: A must visit if you are in shanghai
content: The view from the bund is magnificent ,since the day we reached shanghai , we experienced a lot of smog along the route and in the night the view was getting hasty , but still we enjoyed being there as a tourist , the light show was just amazing , all of us were waiting for a click of " I shanghai " and then they were displaying at the opposite side of the building , somehow we missed visiting the pearl tower and what they say as a bottle opener.

title: Quaint touch of France
content: LOL...we'd just come from Paris, so to see there was a French area in Shanghai was quite "interesting". The buildings are highly ornate and quite different to the buildings in Shanghai.

title: It was nice but that's it
content: Good restaurants, but if you're looking for a real chinese experience, i wouldn't describe it as the place to go. yes the place is nice, lot of restaurants and bars. so if you,re looking for a european break in your chinese holidaym this would be the place.

title: Nice area
content: It's a nice, old area with lots of cafes and restaurants. There's a "museum" here which is the Memorial site of the First National Congress of the Communist Party of China that you can visit for free and the building for the temporary government for Republic Korea is also here. You will also find the display of the 2008 Beijing Olympic's torch in front of One Xintiandi. Need to spend some time here to explore.

title: Go But Dont Buy
content: Very interesting area, i had doubt to visit this attraction but the tour guide insisted to take us there. Thanks to him i loved the area. My advise to you don't buy anything from there, its overpriced because of the area not the product itself. take a look at the pictures . The small shops are everywhere and they are very interesting

title: Charming, upmarket and interesting.
content: Well worth a visit. There are some beautiful little shops and boutiques - perhaps not the cheapest but excellent quality and not all the same "touristy" pieces. Nice places to eat and beautiful little streets and buildings. Also a wonderful cultural museum, actually a former home that has been transformed to give an insight into the history of the area. Very nominal entry fee for the museum.

title: A nice stroll
content: We liked this old and very quaint area, built in the 19th century. It was interesting to see the old buildings against the new.

title: Had a great vibe
content: Loved to walk around and taking pics. Very vibrant. Lots of places to eat. Nice buildings. Wish had more time to explore. Nice park nearby

title: Kind of regret devoting an afternoon to it......
content: Many of the guidebooks recommended a walk round the French Concession...... so we invested some of our time to have a look at what all the fuss was about. I still don't know what all the fuss was about.

title: Overrated are but nice cafes
content: The area is nice but I feel it's a bit overrated. The prices are expensive too but nonetheless an awesome area to be for a nice afternoon coffee break.

title: Bring Your Camera!
content: Beautiful sycamore-lined streets in an area rich in history. Many shops, cafes as other reviewers have mentioned but the absolute must-see is Fuxing Park. Here the citizens practice the waltz, tango, tai chi, singing and enjoying the outdoors. If you are a photographer or an avid people-watcher, do yourself a favor and plan to enjoy the park and all the action for at least an hour. This was my absolute favorite place in four days of touring wonderful Shanghai.

title: Quaint but interesting area
content: Spent a couple of hours walking through the narrow alleys, looking in the shops and bars. Another part of Shanghai that is not well known but definitely a must see place.

title: The amazing old-styled housing of Shanghai "Xin Tian Di"
content: This place is in a historic area of Shanghai and yet it is located within the city center. The first thing I noticed about this amazing area is its unique antique walls with arch stone gates under the shade of beautiful big trees lining up the street. From what I read, Xin Tian Di represents a place where the past has met the present. The old-styled buildings look amazing with narrow alleys along with them. The exterior of these buildings might look very antique but the inside is definitely not. I walked into a few boutiques and cafes and found that they look quite contemporary. Anyhow, the whole place is amazing and I couldn't help but taking a lot of photos of this beautiful corner of Shanghai.

title: Visit the Shikumen house museum while in the Concession
content: While much of the French Concession seems given over to glitzy malls and high end car dealerships, many of the old buildings are renovated "shikumen houses - unique domestic architecture that was French in outward appearance, and Chinese in interior arrangements. There is one unrenovated house that is now a museum - The Shikumen Open House Museum - that will show you what one of these places looked like in the 1920s, complete with the photographs of the upscale family that owned it. It doesn't take long to go through, but it is a good antidote to all the bling.

title: Go for a night stroll in the residential area
content: The French Concession is a historic area full of heritage houses owned by famous politicians, artists, writers and the like. The historic homes come in different styles.

title: Culturally Rich Attraction
content: The concessions reminded me of the era it represents in Shanghai's history. The buildings are in pristine condition and as you walk the area you feel you've transitioned into an authentic French Market!

title: Key place for good bars & restaurants
content: Quite a change from the high rise Shanghai of the city centre. Low rise buildings with many roadside trees. Main...

title: A little bit of Europe in the middle of Shanghai
content: Really liked the Old French Concession. Plenty of bars, cafes & shops. It really lights up at night with plenty of bars & restaurants. Wish I had more time to spend there, I would of really liked to eat a meal there as all the restaurants looked incredible. There are public toilets if you are just going to have a look but not to buy :)

title: Great for shopping, food and relaxing
content: A very nice area with colonial french style buildings and tree lined streets. Clean and safe to walk about. Many good places to eat and shop, there is a mixture of chinese, other asian and western cafes and restaurants. Good in day and in the evening with couple of lovely, well kept parks near by. Going back everytime when in Shaghai.

title: modernized area of town
content: I found the French Concession area part of town to be quite nice with most of the buildings having gone through renovations. The area has lots of trees and there are a few small parks where you will always see people working out.

title: Interesting and Varied Area
content: Dropped by the former French Concession area of Shanghai on my last visit to the city in April 2013. The area is pretty large and taking in most of it will take some time. It is an interesting and in some ways unusual part of Shanghai.

title: Trendy Precinct
content: This is the French district of the Colonial Shanghai era, the buildings are more European in style, there are some...

title: You need a tour guide
content: Old French Concession is like a neighborhood. My suggestion is to take a tour. I was there, and honestly I...

user_loc: 科罗拉多斯廷博特斯普林斯
title: Winding Pathways
content: The French Concession, once designated for the French, is a large area with historic buildings and small walkways tucked in the tiny neighborhoods.

title: A "Most visit" if you are in Shanghai
content: This area gives you a flavour of the old area of Shanghai. It is also one of the more wealthier part offering exhibition and arts, that you may not see in other areas. You are likely to feel at home here quite fast. Enjoy and relax at one of the cafes/restaurants even thought it is a bit pricey.

title: European architecture, history, shopping, dining and beautiful tree lined streets,
content: Must see if beautiful parks and tree lined streets, with interesting boutiques, european restaurants, Sun Yat Sen's house, museums and monuments interest you. Very interesting and relaxing walk through one of the classic neighborhoods surviving from old historic Shanhai.

title: Can't say you have been to Shanghai...
content: ... unless you have walked the French Concession and it is best to experience this area via walking for the most part. You can get there via taxi or several metro lines from anywhere in the city. This is a great area to visit and experience the atmosphere of the old city. The Moeller House, embassies, former houses of many famous artists, authors, and political figures can all be found there. Xintandi [pronounced Shin-tan-dee] is a shopping area that has refurbished and rebuilt old traditional Shanghai style buildings [hutongs]. The site of the first communist party museum in addition to many modern day eateries and bars [Boxing Cat Brewery]. Yes, there is a very popular Starbucks located there where you can take a break and watch all manner of people pass by. Everyone you talk to will have a different suggestion for what to do while in the Concession so don't hesitate to solicit opinions.

title: Take an afternoon stroll
content: Beautiful part of Shanghai, the north side is full of lots of little shops and places to eat where the South is all about the art deco buildings, perfect place to get lost.

title: If you are already here... why not..???
content: I live in this area.. so knon it pretty well. It spreads over a fairly wide and diverse area, but the Tian Zi Fang area and the lane ways near Jing An temple are a treat. There is a lot of modern crap around too, so you have to be adventurous....

title: Not any specific attractions but a lovely, peaceful area to wander through
content: I don't know of any specific attractions in the French Concession but it really lovely to stroll through the tree lined streets, stopping at one of the myriad of cafes for a delicious coffee and treat. Lots of great restaurants in the area. Rather far from Pudong and the Bund and the clothing markets. Do stay in a hotel in one of the lovely alleyways. I didn't do a walking tour with a guide but wish I had.

title: A must do experience
content: Once you have wandered the narrow market precienct and had a good coffee, set out for a walk through this charming district. See the art deco houses, hospital staff, hotels and sicamore trees. I really felt I had a deeper experience3 of shanghai after a couple of hours in this residential district. The famous shopping area is OK too however it is the backstreets that delight.

title: A feel of Europe and France in Shanghai
content: Shanghai is a surprising mix of different kinds of architectures and atmospheres.

title: Atmosphere, atmosphere, atmosphere: my favorite Shanghai neighborhood
content: I visited the French Concession after spending a day each around The Bund/Pudong and the Old City; it was easily my most memorable visit of the three. This is an area of Shanghai that can be appreciated on multiple levels. There are several historic sites in the area along with excellent places to eat from local gigs like Crystal Jade to more "trendy" options such as T8, in addition to innumerable shops and parks. The neighborhood is overall very clean and the overarching trees lend a very elegant air to the surroundings. I would definitely recommend a visit to anyone visiting the city.
